content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												There is no way to sum up the gloryness of this game in words. It's just amazing. The developers of this game were not afraid to go out there and it's very clear that this game was thoroughly thought out, made with love, and most importantly, made for the player.You're a random guy who tries to go about his day and finish some errands. Each errand can be completed in a number of ways, just one of the things that increase the replay value of this game. You can choose to live through the game as a good guy, doing the errands the "right" way, paying your bills, respecting civilians, etc. Or you can be a bad guy and kill anyone you see, steal anything you want, break stuff, etc.Then there is the amount of things you can do. It's almost endless; You can pee on people, you can pour gasoline on them and light them on fire, you can kick them, cut their heads off and play fetch with your dog (oh yeah, you have a dog, and you can get more dogs by giving them dog treats), taze them, sick your dog after them and so many more.The interactivity. The AI is pretty smart. Some will hide, some will run, some won't even be afraid of you, some will attack. They all react exactly how you think they would when being chased by your dog or set on fire or♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on or shot at. They are even aware of the minor details in the world such as sound, doors, cats, dogs and eachother. If something in the world can't be destroyed, then it can be pushed around. Ragdolls also have amusing and sometimes funny results as usual.This game has the mentality of "it's your game, play it how you want to". You don't have to do the errands in order, you don't have to do them right away and there's many things to do besides the errands, but that's for you to discover. If you are one who goes for achievements, this game will certainly provide you with achievements that will take you for a fun ride, and some are not so easy. Like I said, there is no proper way to describe the gloryness of the game, you just have to play it.I highly recommend this game. 10/10.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												My opinionated breakdown review of: POSTAL 2Gameplay: POSTAL 2 is set in a small town in Arizona named Paradise. You will play as Postal Dude (actual name) completing various day to day activities such as: getting milk, getting autographs from Gary Coleman, retrieving mail, and many other trivial activities that end up turning into an all-out gore fest. You see, this game doesn't care. Anything offensive you can think of, it'll probably be in this game. This game is a sandbox set in first-person based off of the Unreal engine. When you first start playing you will notice how open-ended and interactive the world is. Some sections are cut-off due to plot restrictions but usually, you won't get bored of one area. The combat is fairly dumb, but fun. The game's idea of difficulty is more enemies, and as you progress, you will become rivals with many factions. If I had to describe this game in two words, I would say "Murder Simulator." There are many weapons to utilize each with unique effects. Simple things such has scissors can be used as a lethal ninja star immitation. The game is very creative with how you want to kill or torture people (urinating on someone until he/she throws up). Play the game for it's killing, not the story.Art: The game manages to look decent, even by today's standards. There are a lot of copy and paste areas, but each section of the map feels unique enough to grab your attention. You will mostly be looking at blood, vomit, urine, and more blood.Music/sound: The game does little in the music department, other than atmospheric radio. The sound design is decent, most weapons sound like you would expect them to and the screams and remarks of bystanders add to the joy of murdering for no reason.Entertainment Value: The game is short. It would not be uncommon to beat this game in one day (if you did nothing but missions) but based off of the interaction, humor, violence, mature themes, and freedom the game presents, I can see a player coming back to it again and again if they want to murder and pee on people for no reason for some time. It isn't exactly and in-depth game.Score: Based on everything, the game offers nothing but a good murder simulation. The story is lackluster, the sound and art is decent, and the overall missions just consist of go to location, kill everything, leave. For what it's worth, the workshop support does add to the gameplay by giving you new weapons and maps, but at the end of the day, it is a very well done murder sandbox with extremely controversial subjects and content. Play at your own risk.3/5Thank you for reading.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												POSTAL 2 is a brilliant game. It has fantastic replay value (I found myself beating the game quite a few times). It's very funny, and whilst the humor may be no longer topical, you have to remember this was originally released in 2003. Nevertheless, it's still funny. The physics in the game are very well done too, especially the♥♥♥♥♥♥effect. The gore is possibly the most violent and well done in gaming history. The fact that the developers constantly update the game even to this day (the dismemberment feature was originally only in Apocalypse Weekend, and there were a lot fewer weapons in the original release) is astounding. The game does take a while to load each day, but the loading inbetween sections of the town take mere seconds. Overall, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who's not easily offended or grossed out. It's well worth the money and I can't wait to see what kind of game RWS makes next.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Postal 2 is dumb as♥♥♥♥♥♥but in an endearing way. It really helps that the game is total Looney Tunes and doesn't take itself seriously at all. Even the devs poke fun at themselves like for example one of the first things you can do is kill their ingame avatars. The base game is a fun sandbox and the weapons are nice. A neat thing is that you can beat the game non-violently, I did. My biggest complaint with the game is that the Apocalypse Weekend expansion sucks♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's a really medicore corridor shooter at best and terrible one at worst and it ends with an absolutely boring boss fight that drags on way too long. It also ♥♥♥♥ed up my otherwise non-violent run. My advice is to not play those missions. The base five days are worth playing alone. Plus they're releasing a new expansion after more than a decade that's going to be more like the vanilla game so that also adds to the recommendation.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This game is so much fun! It keeps me laughing through the whole game. I've only played for about an hour so far, but the game definitely has my attention. The controls are a bit confusing in the beginning, but you'll get used to them eventually. There are a few minor glitches here and there, but I'm sure the devs will get working on those asap. The weapons are a bit repetitive as so far I've only been able to use a shovel, pistol, machine gun, and a shotgun. Not sure what the rest of the game holds though. So far, it seems like I'm limitless as to what I can do! I've set someone on fire and haven't even been playing the game for 3 hours!  The achievements and trading cards for this game are pretty funny imo. Navigation is a 10/10 for me, as is the gameplay. This game sorta reminds me of GTA, so if you're a fan of GTA, I definitely recommend this game for you. The blood and gore isn't as intense as I thought it would be, which is a good thing because I don't like too much blood and gore. If you don't like it at all, there is an option to toggle it on and off. So far so good. Can't wait to see what the rest of the game holds! 9/10 Weekend deal so grab it fast!

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Postal 2 challenges players to survive a week as The Postal Dude. His week isn't spent behind enemy lines as a guerilla soldier, or fighting off an alien invasion. Postal Dude is spending this week around his own neighborhood, doing mundane errands like cashing his paycheck, buying milk, grabbing some meat for a BBQ, and so on. As it turns out, everyone in Paradise, Arizona is either a jerk, a maniac, a terrorist, or Gary Coleman. On top of that, you're one sandwich short of a six-pack.To give you an idea of how the average play-through will go. I'll describe one of my misadventures.-On the way to getting Gary Coleman's autograph, I murdered several people and batted their heads around with a shovel. The police showed up and threw me in prison. They didn't see the murders, but I couldn't suppress the urge to urinate on them. -Escaping from prison was surprisingly easy. On the way out I scored a police uniform, raided their armory, and...urinated on everyone. I don't have issues, honest!-I doused a club in gasoline and set everyone on fire. There were a couple survivors, thanks to my quick thinking. After urinating on them to put out the fires, I revived them with the stun gun. They have 4th degree burns though so...hmm.-Finally I arrived at the mall. There was a long line for Gary's autograph. Instead of waiting I killed someone that just got their book signed. No urinating was involved this time.This is an open-ended game, and there are always non-violent solutions for every task. In fact you can even complete the game without killing anyone. Taking the easy way out tends to be more fun though. At the very least you'll have to break into a few houses and swipe everyone's kevlar vests, fast food, and crack to keep yourself alive. Saturday and Sunday make up the expansion portion of the game. This...well..this really isn't good. Every other day is open-ended, there's a sense of exploration, and fun to be had in goofing around. The weekend consists of more traditional FPS levels. They're really linear, and you have to deal with almost constant gun-fights. This gets old very quickly. Postal 2 is very much a product of its time as well. The jokes are tasteless (says the guy that urinates on burn victims!) and not at all timely. This version adds a bunch of achievements, with most of them being named after memes. Essentially this game was dated when it came out, and dated even more with its re-release. It's still entertaining and hilarious, just be careful who you talk to when you describe the game.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Ok... This game... I've played over 500 games before in my life... And not a single one got laughing as hard as this one.I have a section in my Steam Library called, 'The Holy Game' and Garry's Mod is in there. That's about to change. This game is the best game I have ever played in my life! I love games that keep me laughing, show complete and utter randomness that you forget that there's even a storyline behind it.Usually in games, I like to do what I'm supposed to do and try not to kill the A.I. this game however, it was just so entertaining to run around killing people with the dumbest sh*t imaginable. I would really like a Postal 2. I don't care about the graphics. In fact, you will end up having so much fun on this game that you will completely forget how bad the graphics are. It's like going back to the original Half Life but now it's actually fun.The voice acting is hilariously stupid but I love it! Especially the main character's voice. The females on this game make me laugh my a** because they sound like (and I'm pretty sure that they actually were) they were used on 11 year old girls. The males also sound like they were acted by a teenage boy. The main character is just... just... Chuck Testa... And Chuck Norris combined.This game is so fantastic that it also deserves a list of the pros and cons:Pros-Can use cats as gun attatchments-Can again cop niorety.-Can be jailed and escape unlike GTA where the cops just kill you-Can go in nearly every single room in the game.-Includes drugs-Steam Workshop-Variety of Game Modes-Different story lines-Killer cats-Pet dogs-Different weapons-Can remove limbs from bodies-Your drug trip without getting high-Can get high on cat nip-Police actually give you a chance to drop your gun unlike you know what-Police have different guns-Some civilians supprise you with a gun hidden in there a** crack.-Can rob a bank unlike you know what-Can have some good physics unlike you know what-Can blow up cars and make them go flying-Can kick people in the face-Includes Achievements-Can kick open doors-Includes zombies-Can stick sledgehammers up cows a**'s-Can die by cats-Can't die from stupid hights like in minecraft-Can lose limbs and still be alive (unless it's your head).Cons-Bad GraphicsBare in mind that I've only played half of the first day out of seven on only one game mode...This is my largest review so far and this game deffinately deserves it! Well done to whoever made this, this is the best game I have ever played. I would reccomend this to anyone unless you're some boring fart who just wants to play World Of Warcraft all day.Overall I would rate this game:21/10Would smoke cat - nip again.

number of helpful: 121 of 228 people (53%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Let's get a bit of context first, shall we?I do like this kind of humour, (especially political satire), and controversy isn't an issue, as long as it's done well. I like TV shows such as Archer or films such as the brilliant Team America. Probably the most obvious comparison to this game, South Park has always seemed to be more of a hit and miss whenever I've found myself watching it. So having heard a reasonable amount about the POSTAL series over the years, I was mildly interested and picked this up for a dirt cheap price the other day during yet another Steam sale. After playing it for a bit, I was disappointed. Quite simply, I don't find POSTAL 2 funny, or even interesting, to play. I understand what it is trying to do, as well as the appeal and success of the game. But controversy for controversy's sake is a huge error when it comes to this kind of humor. Gameplay itself is nothing more than average for the mid-2000s period and I doubt you're here for graphical fidelity. Placing my own thoughts aside though, hats off to RWS for having the balls to continue to release and support the series.. it's a good thing that the gaming industry has this kind of thing, even if it doesn't work for me personally.But chances are you'll still enjoy it, so if you're in the mood, ignore my review and by all means, enjoy. It's not a "bad" game. I don't hate this game, and no, I'm not a religious conserative or lobbyist. Quite the opposite in fact. I just didn't find POSTAL 2 enjoyable. Find out if works for you.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I was honestly scared that this game would suck (the "Proffesional" critics said it did) but I have to say I love this game, and I don't regret buying it at all. The game is of course offensive, but it's very funny, and even though on the surface it may appear to be offensive for shock value,  there are actually messages and commentary behind the very offensive stuff (for the most part.) Postal 2 is funny, however, for more than scripted scenes; the random shenanigans that can happen in the open world can be quite amusing and fun to watch, especially doing something like kicking someone, having them pull a gun on you, then have them (and possibly the whole town) get into a fire-fight with the police.The story in Postal obviously isn't the important part, it's simply a big fetch quest around the town of paradise, however it's not hard get lost on the way there, as it's easy to get caught up in the fun of slaughtering people. The game has a wide selection of weapons, which makes attacking random civs and police interesting. Some weapons such as the pistol, baton, shotgun, and assult rifle are common, while some are area specific, rare, and for the most part more interesting. You can get an axe to hack at peoples limbs. If they survive a hit to the arm, they run around screaming until you finish them. Or how about a can of gasoline, to light anyone you want on fire? Burning someone causes them to run around in circles, igniting anyone or anything they touch, eventually (unless killed or extinguished first) they collapse in a pile of searing charred flesh, barely clinging to life, free to be kicked to death as you please. But the best weapon in the game is one you start with: urine. The ability to♥♥♥♥♥♥on people, believe it or not, is one of the most powerful weapos, as it causes people to stop what they're doing and rub their face. Or, if you get lucky, they might puke and completely stand still for 5 seconds or so, leaving you plenty of time to kill them. Postal's gore is awesome, and with so many varied ways to kill (My favorite is hacking all of someone's limbs off, burning them to a crisp, then as they beg for you to end it, kick them until they explode) you never feel bored travelling between areas. Definetly ignore whatever stupid 0/10 reviews you see, this game is awesome! Oh, and it's still getting updates, which means you can bet on even more cool content coming.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Honestly the greatest sandbox fps game in the whole everywhere.Unlike in Postal where your goal is to just slaughter everything that breathes, Postal 2 sees you living out the life of Postal Dude. All you do is simple errands, and whether or not you want chunks of decapitated human heads sprayed all over the landscape is completely up to you. The game is a FPS, rather than a isometric shooter, and you can do pretty much just about anything imaginable. You can put a cat silencer on your guns, set fire to everything,♥♥♥♥♥♥on people, or just go on a generic rampage.But then again, you can also act like a normal person, fulfil your common errands, and not be a general jackass psychopath to everyone around you.The game's tag line is "It's only as violent as you are!". This is one of the most brutally violent games in existence, which means its one of the absolute best games in existence.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												POSTAL 2, where do I have to start? Well, let's put it in this way. If you have a annoying bully at school, and you just want to like, chop his head off, POSTAL 2 is great to practice that. Just kidding, but POSTAL 2 is a madness simulator to me, you can basically do everything. You want to fetch with your dog? Done. Are you in for kicking someone's monitor into stuck into a wall? Possible! You want to pee on your ex-wife Melissa? A-Okay!  Do you want to walk on electrical wire at 8 feet high while hoping not to be shocked? Maybe.  You want to steal your neighbour Daniel's taser and taser him to death? Why not? You want to throw a molotov-cocktail at people in a gaybar? Okay, now you've crossed the line. Seriously. So, are you ready for some crazy crap coming up in a small village in Arizona made by some developers which run all the time with scissors in their hands? The game is actually from 2003, but POSTAL 2 is still played by many across the world. Running With Scissors made even a totally new DLC for the game, called POSTAL 2: Paradise Lost, not so long ago, in 2015. I highly recommend this game, and this is one of the best games I've ever played. It's definitely worth your money, especially when it's on sale. And when it's on sale, you should buy Paradise Lost too. Great game. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Postal 2 teaches some very important life lessons... I'm serious, though... Just hear me out on this. Running with Scissors has sprinkled life lessons to and fro in this glorious game of theirs that yes everyone, even children, will benefit from (Now, far be it from me to say that the parents who see this game and think it's nothing but trash-talk and gore, not "worthy" for their feeble-minded children to suffer through are evil, but any parent who would deprive their children of these life lessons, are well... evil). "Well," you may be wondering, "what are these life lessons that you go on about? Will you ever get to the point?" My answer to the first question would be "SHUT UP, I'M GETTING THERE!" and my answer to the second question is... "Yeah sure, whatever..."THE LIFE LESSONS1. If you ask a celebrity to sign a book for you and they turn you down, it's okay! Just dump a load of gasoline on their heads, light them on fire, pee the fire out, steal the signature of the celebrity from someone else as they run away in terror because you just lit a guy on fire, hide from the cops in a well-concealable water fountain until they give up, and laugh as you run all the way home to sell the autograph on eBay because, as you know (maybe...), celebrities signatures are worth much more after they are deceased...2. YOU HATE MALLS, YOU ♥♥♥♥ING HATE THEM, THEY'RE CONFUSING AND SCARY AND YOU HATE THE LEVEL DESIGNER(S) OF THIS GAME, IF THERE WAS ANY WAY TO SKIP THE MISSIONS WHERE YOU HAD TO GO INTO THE MALL, YOU WOULD!3. If you feel frustration at the level designer(s) of a game, go down to the company building and take your wrath out on them with that shotgun that you found behind a dumpster! It's better than holding it all in! :D4. It's okay to kill someone you hate! Just make sure the cops are not around! :D5. If someone makes fun of you while you are wearing a gimp suit, PEE IN THEIR MOUTHS IMMEDIATELY, THEY DESERVE IT!6. Never wait in lines. If you want something but there is a line, just pee on everyone (unless if there's a cop... God, I learned that one the hard way... (-.-))! *EXCEPTION* If there is a cop in the line, pull out your gun and start firing until you or everyone else around you is choking on their own blood and vomit!7. If you are on fire, DO NOT PANIC! Tilt at a slight angle and pee on yourself! If you are a woman... lol, good luck with that...8. It's ok to show the ladies your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in public, but remember our rule about the cops, k? ;)9. If you see one of those Running With Scissors guys running around, throw scissors into their eye sockets and laugh at the irony.10. Don’t have money to pay for some stupid traffic ticket? Rob your local bank! The cops will be glad to take your stolen money. :3In conclusion, these examples and more have all proven to be knowledge that a young man/woman will need on this journey that we call life. This is why I believe that all parents should purchase this game for their young children immediately. If not for the awesome blood and gore… buy it for the life lessons.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												While I say I recommend this game, it's hard to say if this is a good game or not. It's a masterpiece in one man's hands and a disgusting, horrifying putrid mess to another. It all FUNCTIONS well, but beauty is in the eye of the beholder. If your definition of "beauty" is a murderspree game that was meant to cause controversy.The story is simple - you're a lower class guy with a goatee and a gross set of clothes doing your job as a regular citizen with a wife living in a run-down trailer. You try to make it through your week in the most mundane way possible - walk everywhere doing errand to errand. Get milk, return a book, cash a paycheck. Normal stuff. Your week is however, ruined. Protestors at the game company you work for (also the devs of the game you're playing), protestors at your library... Everything just goes badly. Murdering everyone against you helps.The gameplay is a minor issue with the game. The controls are absolutely fine, everything works well enough, but walking from point A to B is monotonous and boring. Once you get to the action though, everything is a little bit better. However, most characters you fight against are programmed with awful AI and the only way you die is either in suicide, a  few cheap shots or fighting at close range when they have a gun. It's only challenging on the higher difficulties because of high damage guns on them and low damage guns on you. It's far from a game that you use your mind with.The graphics are pretty meh. The in-jokes put in by the devs sometimes are just .jpegs with a lot of compression. It was the early 2000s though, so it's excusable for the time.But you don't care about that stuff, right? You want to play this game to feel like an immature child and cause as much murder to take care of your anger as fast as possible. That's what I did. Content that can be regarded as offensive can be poor depiction of protestors, hyperviolence, optional animal cruelty,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on terrorist graves... It's too much to list. RWS thought of what is basically a  lot  of offensive stuff. There's even Nazi-istic comments you can get The POSTAL Dude to say. Like I said in the beginning of the review, beauty is in the eye of the beholder. If you think exploitation is all for laughs, go for it. If you just want to♥♥♥♥♥♥off your parents or your boss, go for it. This game is a subjective masterpiece or a subjective pile of garbage depending on who you ask. Reviews won't do much good in describing the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												A game that up to this moment is continuously supported by it's developers, which are always around to help when any issue pops up.The world is free for you to explore and roam around. In fact, you'll end up raiding the whole city as you are trying to reach a certain location just because you can.Every day you get a few errands to complete and multiple ways to do so. Unlike other games, the errands seem to be very simple, some tasks that anyone could face- buying milk, paying a ticket at the police station, get steaks- nothing could go wrong.The game is as violent as you are, you can either go postal and kill your way out of anything, or try to peacefully make your way out of trouble without getting killed (that's the real challenge).There are tons of secrets hidden by the map designers that contain either easter eggs and/or hidden weapons and items that will help you as you progress trough the game.Aside from the fun gameplay, badass one-liners and humorous jokes, the game is not entirely flawless. One of the most stressing features is the loading zones, meaning that whenever you will go around a corner or trough a tunnel you will most likely face a loading screen. The wait time isn't that long, usually taking ~10 seconds, but for a game where traveling is a key feature it starts to get on your nerves pretty quickly. Another flaw is the not-so-great hit reg system, which will cause weapons such as the m4 and m5 to be nearly useless at times, but with an old engine like p2 is running on, the game itself can't be blamed for these.However, unless you're an actual fan of old games that is used to such issues games used to have, you should probably stay away from it. I just can't get enough.Just don't forget the Rocky Road.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												 Postal 2  is a first-person shooter video game by Running with Scissors, and it is the sequel to the 1997 game Postal. Both are intentionally highly controversial due to high levels of violence and stereotyping. Unlike its predecessor, Postal 2 is played completely in first-person based on the Unreal Engine. Scenes of the game can be seen in the music video of the Black Eyed Peas single "Where Is the Love?".In 2004, New Zealand banned Postal 2 due to "gross, abhorrent content"  and Australia later banned the game due to "excessive abhorrent content". On May 1, 2007, Malaysia banned the game outright due to "very high impact violence & offensive depictions of cruelty". The game is also banned in Germany, France and temporarily banned for sale in Sweden. The games were later legally made available worldwide through GOG.com in 2009 and later on Steam in 2012.The game received a mixed reception from critics upon its release in 2003, with some reviewers going so far as to give the game a score of zero, while others argued in favor of the game's concept and implementation. Regardless, the game was successful enough to receive several expansions and to be included in multiple compilations, and a film adaptation of the game and its predecessor was made in 2008.Plot  In Postal 2, the player takes on the role of the Postal Dude, a tall and thin red-headed man with a goatee, sunglasses, a black leather trench coat, and a t-shirt with a grey alien's face printed on it. Postal Dude lives in a trailer park in the small town of Paradise, Arizona, with his nagging wife, who is identified in the credits as simply, the 'Postal Dude's ♥♥♥♥♥'. The game's levels are split into days of the week starting Monday and finishing Friday.At the beginning of each day, Postal Dude is given several tasks to accomplish, such as 'get milk', 'confess sins', and other seemingly mundane tasks. The object of Postal 2 is to finish all of the tasks throughout the week, and the player can accomplish these tasks in any way he or she wishes, be it as peaceful and civilly as possible, or as violent and chaotically as possible. It is possible, if occasionally difficult, to complete most tasks without engaging in battle, or at least, harming or killing other characters, as evidenced by the game's tagline: "Remember, it's only as violent as you are!". The daily tasks can be accomplished in any order the player desires, and the game also includes one task that is activated only when Postal Dude urinates, in which the player is tasked with getting treatment for gonorrhea after Postal Dude discovers he has the infection.Throughout the course of the game, Postal Dude must put up with being provoked by other characters on a regular basis. He is given the finger, mugged, attacked by various groups of protesters, and is harassed by an obnoxious convenience store owner/terrorist and his patrons who cut before Postal Dude in the "money line". During the game, Postal Dude also encounters a marching band, a murderous toy mascot named Krotchy, the Paradise Police Department and its SWAT team, overzealous BATFE agents, the Arizona Army National Guard, an eccentric religious cult, cannibalistic butcher shop workers, fanatical Al-Qaeda terrorists, and former child actor Gary Coleman, among many others.By Friday afternoon, the final day in the game, the apocalypse occurs and societal collapse soon follows, with all law and order breaking down. Cats begin to fall out of a darkly-colored sky, and almost everyone in town becomes heavily armed, with random gun battles breaking out in the streets. Despite this, Postal Dude returns home to his trailer as normal, where he then gets into an argument with his wife, who demands that Postal Dude explain why he never picked up the ice cream she asked for at the beginning of the game. Postal 2 then ends with a gunshot being heard, before being kicked to the end credits.Gameplay  One of the major concepts of Postal 2 is that it is meant to be a "living world", a simulation of a tongue-in-cheek off-kilter town. Game characters live out their lives completely separate from the actions of Dude; walking around town, buying and selling merchandise, and even engaging in random shootouts with each other and the police.The town features many cars but they are all "useless exploding props", according to Dude, and cannot be driven, although they can be blown up and sent flying into the air. In addition to cats and dogs, other animals present are elephants; these animals can be shot or set on fire—or simply annoyed by the player walking into them—causing them to trumpet with rage and attack anyone within stomping distance. A bizarre feature is the ability to pick up cats as an inventory item. When used, Postal Dude shoves the barrel of the currently equipped firearm into the cat's♥♥♥♥♥♥ as a 'silencer'. Every time a shot is fired, the cat meows in apparent agony, and the gunshot is muffled. After nine shots the cat has run out of lives and it will fly from the end of the weapon. Most dogs have the ability to befriend the Dude if he feeds them a continual supply of dog biscuits or feeds them any other food . Once a canine's loyalty has been earned, the dog will attack anyone who attacks the Dude, or alternatively, anyone whom the Dude attacks. Dogs will also chase and kill cats, and play fetch with the Dude's inventory items and also severed heads. There were also going to be cows included in the game, but they were left unprogrammed. They did appear in Apocalypse Weekend and the A Week in Paradise modification.The game also features a cameo by Gary Coleman, acting as himself, who appears early on as the objective of one of the game's tasks . The player can choose to fight and kill Coleman or simply have the book signed peacefully . If the book does get signed, the Dude remarks to Coleman that he really loved him in Facts of Life . Regardless of the Dude's actions, the police storm the building in an attempt to arrest Gary Coleman and a gunfight ensues which invariably results in Coleman's apparent demise, with or without the player's help. Later on in the game he can also be seen in the Police Station, when the player escapes from his cell he also frees everyone else—including Coleman, who can be seen running alongside Krotchy. Coleman apparently survives as he can be seen in the Apocalypse Weekend expansion, bandaged up in the hospital .Release   Expansions    Share the Pain    The updated edition of the game, entitled Postal 2: Share the Pain included a multiplayer mode. The Macintosh and Linux versions of Postal 2 shipped only as Postal 2: Share the Pain. Share the Pain has since far eclipsed the original production version of Postal 2 in all markets. As part of a promotional effort to advertise the Postal film, in 2008 RWS released the multiplayer part of the game as freeware, minus the unrealed based level editor PostEd.Apocalypse Weekend    Apocalypse Weekend is an expansion pack to Postal 2 released by Running with Scissors on August 1, 2004 for Microsoft Windows, and September 28, 2005 for the Mac OS X and Linux versions. Apocalypse Weekend expands the reaches of Paradise with new maps and missions, set on Saturday and Sunday, adds new weapons and foes, and raises the gore and violence to an even greater level. It was later included in both the Postal Fudge Pack and Postal X : 10th Anniversary compilations alongside Share the Pain and several fan produced mods, including A Week in Paradise which allows content from Apocalypse Weekend to appear in the original game as well as allowing the expansions levels to be played as part of the original five day campaign.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Postal 2, an old classic brought back to life. A game where a dude goes postal. Oh and his name is Postal Dude, too! What happens when your day goes to♥♥♥♥♥♥ Well, you might tase a dog. Or perhaps shout at people's faces telling them they're going to get killed unless they get to the ground, and yet they stare back at you clueless of how big of a psycho you are. Or perhaps you light some folks of fire, immediately regretting that you did, you try to get the fire out by peeing on them. With the addition of Multiplayer and constant updates(and workshop as well), what could go wrong? Find out for yourselves in this hilariously comical game and unleash your inner psycho.P.S: If you enjoyed GTA:SA you'll like this, too. And if you're a fan of Postal1/2, Manhunt or similar, check out Hatred on Greenlight.(user discretion is advised). Oh and all the random events that go on... reminds me of Bad Day LA.>I'd give it a 10/10>Pros: Despite old it still gets updates, achievements and cards, updated graphics and all, humoristic and dark, violence is optional... but we know you'll do it, fair price.>Cons: None so far.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Postal 2 is the beloved sequel to the game where a guy in a trenchcoat heard voices in his head tell him to murder the entire population with military grade weapons. Having last been committed to a mental asylum, we find the Postal Dude strangely sane with a much more placid view on life. Also, he seems to have married a bossy wife, moved into a trailer in Paradise, AZ gotten a job at a video game design and publishing company (RWS Inc.) and even still has his dog! Way to go, P. Dude! Unfortunately, Paradise seems to be about as stable as the cauldron of chemicals where gunpowder was accidentally invented.     Postal 2 has a free-roaming environment with goals to be accomplished in no particular order, or even in no specified way. You, the Postal Dude, are given an errand list by your wife each day and must go accomplish your goals, like confessing your sins at church, picking up milk from the store, etc. However, every time you get close to accomplishing these things, something insane happens, like video game protesters raid your job office when you go to pick up your paycheck, or rednecks try to murder you when you buy somebody's favorite Christmas tree (in July). You then get to decide whether you want to be the pacifist and flee the scene, be the hero and fight off the bad guys or be the psycho and murder everyone you see. As RWS Inc. so proudly advertised, the game is only as violent as you are.      The graphics in this game are much more polished then the previous game, this time giving us a 3D first person environment to roam around in and a much more accurate targeting system. The music in the game, instead of only being frightening experimental percussion music like the first one, was actually collected from local bands in Tucson, the hometown  of Running With Scissors Inc. Being the sequel, the game also has a much bigger arsenal, ranging from military weapons to a variety of firearms, to many blunt and sharp objects to scissors and so on. The only real problem I have with this game is that nobody seems to be doing the multiplayer when I jump on, but maybe that's just me. Aside from that, if you have a strong stomach and are okay with offensive jokes delivered in a gruesome yet silly way, I highly recommend this game.

												Had a bad day at work? School? Life in general and you want to take it out on something or someone, but don't want to spend time in jail? Then Postal 2 is the game for you. A few hours of playing and you will feel much better. This game however, is NOT for those with no sense of humor. I picked it up on sale just to see what all the controversy was about and I love it. Yes, it will offend some, but what you do in the game, we all have wanted to do in life to others at some point. I would recommend this game to those with a good sense of humor and who doesn't take things so seriously.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												Postal 2 is exactly what you make of it. Yes, it can be a gruesome, unsavory, albeit cartoony, experience, and the game does push you to that end most of the time, but it can also be a open world game that allows you to explore a satirical world filled with both hilarious situations and expectations that speak volumes about paranoid, and in many ways complacent, mid-2000s America. In many ways, it shows how trivial the concerns of the time actually were in the grand scheme of things. Postal 2 needs to be given more credit for pushing the envelope for games; what was once considered taboo was torn apart and amplified in this game. Wholly recommended as an experience.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												What can I say. I bought Postal 2 11+ years ago in a gamestop store for $50 when it was only a singleplayer game and I was just freshly addicted to pc gaming. Was hooked on the game from the 1st 5 minutes in as it was the most outragous game I'd ever played at that point. Hacking heads off with a shovel and kicking them around like soccer balls,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in people's faces until they puked, pouring gas all over a bunch of "alternative lifestyle" people dancing in a gay bar and setting them on fire, training stray dogs to attack anyone who attacked me.....and that's just during day 1.  Basically you live 5 days in the life of "The Postal Dude" and although you have a few chores to do each day that allow you to progress to the next day, the game is totally non-linear and open world. You play how you want to play and at what pace and spend as much time as you want exploring and discovering (and there's lot's to discover) as you want.   Then they finally released "Share the Pain", the version of Postal 2 that included multiplayer. Even though the network code wasn't the greatest and it was always a little buggy it quickly became my most played game for the next couple years. I started a clan, started running game servers for the 1st time, and eventually learned the unreal editor and made probably around 30 custom mp maps for the game.  Anyway to make a long story medium, even though the multiplayer community is scarce and pretty much nothing but super modded servers, the single player part of the game is well worth $10 any day of the week. The game is still being updated and patched often more then 11 years later and RWS is about to release a new expansion to the story/game which is looking even better then the original.   If you aren't easily offended, love to laugh your♥♥♥♥♥off, and want to♥♥♥♥♥♥in a cops face then buy this game now!

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												HEY, BABY! WANNA FEEL MY 3 INCH DIK?!?!?!?!I never understood why Postal 2 is considered bad, even by people who love it.The voice acting is amazing, the writing is very self aware and laugh out loud funny, the gameplay is extremely fun, very well made and amazing to mess with, the art design is unique and memorable, its tonetically consistent, etc...I can point to hundreds of games which do any/all those things way worst than Postal 2, even great games. The game may market and structure itself as "bad or stupid", but it is definitely talented and smart in executing that.Sure, it's a stupid game. But so are Metal Gear Solid, Devil May Cry or Dead Rising.That doesn't matter. What matters is, as lord Plinkett would say, how well it resonates with the audience. Play Medal of Honor: Warfighter and Postal 2 and tell me which experience stuck with you the most.Postal 2 is great in the same ways Deadpool and Jackass are. And nobody would even dare call those "objectively bad"

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												This is definitely one of those games you're either going to love, or you're going to absolutely hate.It's a cult classic and almost a straight parody of the late 90s and early 2000s "Videogames make people violent" debates popular of those times. At the time of it's release there was no other game as politically incorrect, dark and downright disturbing as this and... I love it.The gameplay is average.The guns and gunplay are extremely poor.The AI is either extremely stupid, or downright unfair.The Graphics, even for it's time were weak.The map design is lack-lusterThe sound design and music is extremely average.Despite all this, Postal 2 is still one of the greatest games I've ever bloody played.And for the $10 steam is asking, you don't really have anything to lose. You at least owe it to yourself to try one of the most, if not the most controversial game ever made. 11/10

The game is entertaining and if you can get past the old graphics, its definately worth playing. On all max settings its ok. Gameplay is old-school, but fun.  Has crashed to desktop a bunch of times, which sucks.Final word, play it to see what the fuss was all about and see if you still think its that offensive. Definately worth picking up when its on sale.7/10

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												This is definitely one of those games you're either going to love, or you're going to absolutely hate.It's a cult classic and almost a straight parody of the late 90s and early 2000s "Videogames make people violent" debates popular of those times. At the time of it's release there was no other game as politically incorrect, dark and downright disturbing as this and... I love it.The gameplay is average.The guns and gunplay are extremely poor.The AI is either extremely stupid, or downright unfair.The Graphics, even for it's time were weak.The map design is lack-lusterThe sound design and music is extremely average.Despite all this, Postal 2 is still one of the greatest games I've ever bloody played.And for the $10 steam is asking, you don't really have anything to lose. You at least owe it to yourself to try one of the most, if not the most controversial game ever made. 11/10

												Postal 2 is a diamond in the rough.  It has some problems like hit detection, lots of load screens (on the plus side, they do load fairly quickly) and a mildly annoying warning screen when you first load the game up - Every time.  That being said, this game is just stupid fun.  It seems like every day you come across new weapons, my favourites being the hand axe and the sledgehammer.  The squidgy noise when someones head explodes is insanely satisfying.  You can light people on fire,♥♥♥♥♥♥on them to put them out, shove the barrel of you gun up a stray cats bumhole, chop off limbs, and use the world as your toilet.  You can also shoot terrorists if you're into playing the role of world police too.  Or if you picked up this game thinking it was your typical FPS and you can't go thirty seconds without shooting someone of a different race in the face.All in all, Postal 2 is a stupid game that's meant to be stupid and succeeds very well in being just that.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												POSTAL 2, the rightful winner of the 'Best game which got a massive game-changing patch 11 years after its release'.With all the recent controversy about Hatred hitting Steam and causing some massive outrage by some moral guardians for reasons not even related to the game, I thought that it was about time to take a look at the title which caused a boatload of outrage from the moral guardians a decade ago.After the modest success of Postal 1, both at gaining a fanbase and receiving media outrage alike, Running with Scissors decided to take a totally different direction than the unhinged and distressing tone of the original game with Postal 2. In a valliant effort to not♥♥♥♥♥♥off as many people as possible, RWS decided that Postal 2 should start with the most harmless thing they could think of: Going to the store to buy a carton of milk. Unfortunately, stuff goes rather south in almost every way in Postal 2 in the most hilarious of ways.To start about Postal 2, the base game is split up into five days, wherin you must perform totally mundane-seeming tasks in the open-world sandbox town of Paradise, Arizonia, such as buying milk from the store, going to your job, and getting people to sign your petition to make whiny people play more videogames, for example. But stuff goes never the easy way in Postal 2. Such as arriving at work, getting called to the office to hear that you are being sacked on the spot as a dozen of outraged people storm the building in a violent protest against videogames. Or what to think of taking a wrong turn while walking around the open-world town ,as I somehow walked straight into the local terrorist base. Two hours and five signs and a bigger killcount than Hot Shots:Part Deux, I walked out with enough weaponry to arm a town at least thrice. Stuff rapidly escalates in Postal 2 like that in the most absurd kind of ways.While Postal 2 at its core is a very peaceful game. Or at least, the base game can be played though without killing anyone. You can be pretty much the only sane guy in the town as stuff rapidly goes more to hell and people get madder and madder as the days go by. It is more of a game of how long it does take for the player to snap and to play ball sports with the heads of the troublemakers, to say so. The game is as violent as the player. Which still♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the moral guardians off, as did it♥♥♥♥♥♥off many reviewers back in the day giving the game straight zeroes for it.And boy, does Postal 2 give the player a lot of choices in literally going postal. While in the first day of the game the weapons are pretty on the cookie-cutter and boring side, as the week passes, more and more interesting weapons and ways for harm come up. The player's arsenal range up from the usual FPS stuff like Deagles and M16's with the SPAS-12 threwn in, to the insanely unconventional stuff, such as scissors, napalm launchers, cow heads, chemical rockets and boomerang machetes. Along with the even more unconventional functions of the game, such as being able to use toilets for their real purpose, kicking everything and using catnip to slow time, Postal 2 sets up the scene for interesting sandbox action. Throw in AI getting more on edge as the game progresses and the map being chock-full of secrets rewarding exploration, and you got yourself a sandbox you can entertain yourself with for quite a while.Included in the game is also the first expansion pack of the game, Apocalypse Weekend. Unfortunately, Apocalypse Weekend isn't  in the open-world sandbox style of the base week, and focuses on two more days, where you are railroaded in small 'kill stuff' errands and long levels you have to battle yourself through. The pacing is unfortunately all over the place. The small errands with its maps shouldn't take you longer than 10 minutes each, and they are quite frankly pretty boring. The long levels are really chock-full of enemies to blow to pieces with your varied arsenal, and some of them are long enough to get eventually tiring on the higher difficulties to get through, mostly because of the enemy variance in those levels being stale. Even though Apocalypse Weekend added many weapons to Postal 2, which then have been put in the base game, Apocalypse Weekend shouldn't warrant more than one playthrough.Luckily enough, Running With Scissors is busy making their second expansion for this game, Paradise Lost, which will go back to the open-world sandbox spread over a week, which is due to come out next Spring. Along with the huge number of stuff they added in last year's patches, including new weapons, Workshop functionality and the official-making of some popular mods, Running With Scissors is still showing their dedication to their flagship title even 12 years after its inital release. Postal 2 might not be an absolute world-beater, but it is sure one of the more unique games to have come out, despite the stigma against it.

												I beg to you, DO NOT underestimate this game. People call it ''Boring'', because they probably not have finished the first three objectives. The people who find it ''Offensive'', may or may not know it's a comedy/satire, and take everything personally. The ''Gross-Out Humor'', is not as common as critics exaggerate.  After the previous game where he kills everyone in town,''Postal Dude'' moves to Paradise, Arizona with his darling morbidly obese wife. The only problem I had with this is that in the ending of Postal 1, has The Postal Dude get a psychological breakdown, then end up in a mental hospital. Everything about that is forgotton. Anyways, The Dude's wife nags him to do common errands, like buying some milk from a ethnic store. There are many outcomes to this.1.Buy the milk like a legal individual, and get insulted for being, ''unclean''.2.Shoplift the milk, which activates security, and fight Habib and the terrorists in the building.3.Get the milk, and kill everyone.4.Shoplift the milk, and find a secret underground area where mutant dogs try to kill you.5.Shoplift the milk, run upstairs and break through the window like a badass.Of course, the law enforcment can arrest you for being a Maniac.You Could:A: Kill him.B: Bribe him.C: Accept your arrest.D: Run away.E: Stand there like an idiot and get killed.Your actions have consequences, so be wise before♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥everywhere. There are more than♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and cussing, so give this game a try.Don't trust the overly harsh reviews from know-it-all professional game critics, if you like social/political satire, GO BUY NOW, YOU MIGHT BE DIE BEFORE YOU KNOW IT. That is all.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Im going to be blunt with this game, no tagine or anything, if there was the option on here to give BOTH a thumbs up and a thumbs down, that would be the best way to go along with it.This is because that this game happens to mix some really great gaming goodness along with a whole load of poor design choices mixed in with a heavy dose of content that pushes the taste boundaries heavily.Lets take the good first. The design of the main game is great, wandering around the town feels great, theres plenty to explore in the sandbox world, plenty to see and find and loads of hidden easter eggs. At no point does the gamespace feel samey or confusing. The actual structure of the main game works brilliantly too.Each day you are given seemingly 'Mundane' tasks to complete such as 'Get Milk', 'Get Paycheck' and the like. However it openly gives you the option on what YOU want to do to complete the missions. Do you want to be a pacifist and try and run through the game without killing? You can do that! Do you want to just go 'Postal' and shoot up the place? Yep! Do you want to cash yoyr 'Paycheck' by robbing the bank? Its all there.Where the bad comes in however is some of the gameplay, the actual engine isnt smooth, there isnt really any music of any note at all and the graphics have aged quite badly over the years. Bugs are aplenty as well, both annoying bugs and gamebreaking bugs are present with plenty of clipping, invisible walls, AI bugging out and wanted levels that refuse to vanish no matter what you do (or dont do). The other big 'Bad' comes with the weekend addon that destroys the open ended gameplay of the original week and forces you down a specific path.Oh and lets not forget the 'Offensive' nature of the game which may put some people off totally. Here we have blood, sex, drugs, using cats as silencers, camp stereotypes, arab stereotypes, urine, feces and the (now made even more potentially offensive given he is dead) appearance of Gary Coleman (And yes, you can murder him ingame too). Essentially avoid if you are offended easily or even moderately.And that about wraps it up. Once again. Thumbs up, Thumbs down and hard to just say right out if its bad or good. Hope this description has helped with things if you are planning to buy!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is a great game for anyone looking to blow off some Steam (pun intended). Released back in 2003 it still holds up after 12 years, both gameplay and entertainment wise. Postal 2 actually supersedes a lot of current releases when it comes to it's fluid physics for water, gasoline and even the p-i-s-s physics. The Steam version of Postal 2 includes the core game of Postal 2, Postal 2: Share The Pain (The Multiplayer Component), Postal 2: Apocalypse Weekend (an expansion pack for the original Postal 2 released back in 2005 which adds Sunday and Saturday), and finally Postal 2: A Week in Paradise (A mod developed by Resurrection Studios which adds the ability to play through both the core game of Postal 2 and Apocalypse Weekend in one sitting, with additional weapons such as the Chainsaw).If you want the Eternal Damnation mod you will either have to pick up The Fudge Pack (which also includes Postal 1, and other additional content like game trailers released prior E3), or download it for free and install it as an addon for your Postal 2 Steam Version of the game. This also doesn't include Akella's officially unofficial Штопор Жжот addon released back in 2005.Share The Pain could USE some (a lot actually) updates, it doesn't seem it has been updated ever since it's release as freeware in 2008; resulting in terrible connection problems, frequent disconnects, and barren list of servers. But Postal 2 is all about the Singleplayer experience, however, a mod or an expension implementing Co-Op would be a long-awaited and a welcome feature, allowing you to play the entire week with your friends would be a blast and add a lot of hours to anyone's playthroughs with additional replayabilty value to it's Singleplayer "campaign".The game overall runs at a steady framerate, whether you're playing it on a PC or a Mac. The only issues I had were some hard crashes of the game due to some missions getting stuck and the entire Steam client crashing - but with constant auto-saving this isn't a big issue. Overall, this is a great game and still gives me a massive nostalgia boost.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Another game that would really benefit from a "mixed" recommendation.  This is a hard game to rate, because it's based on the player more than the game.  But there is a game behind it that needs to be reviewed.So the game is an old 13 year old game (released in 2003 so the future people have the actual time scale).   When Postal was popular with the mass murdering gameplay, Running With Scisssors worked on a sequel, and took their time, 6 years later, Postal 2 came out, and it's certainly different. 3d graphics versus an isometric game, story instead of random murder, and actually a very different tone as well. The problem is similar to other games it hasn't aged amazing.  13 year old 3d technology is quite interesting to see.  At the same time, Postal 2 is unlike any other game, and that's both a positive and a negative. Postal 2 tries very hard to be edgy, but it does so in a way that definitely makes it almost a time capsule.  Putting muslim suicide bombers in the game in 2003, was extremely tasteless, now... Not as much?   Osama Bin Laden's name is in the game, is that edgy any more?   Shooting bullets through cats (in oddly enough not as tasteless a way as someone would do now) I think a majority of the humor of the game has actually fallen away.   I mean there's a voting joke and it's referencing the 2000 election... It's actually a little funny, but that's one kind of humor you're going to get.   The other?  Well there's a way to pee on, anyone you want.   You have a very juvenile humor in this game, and yet it kind of works on some level.  The thing is the entire game tries VERY hard to be edgy, so if you can be offended, you will be.  Almost every woman is big breasted, and I don't mean 'there's a lot of Buxom characters'.  No, there's like ONE female player model and it's a big breasted woman, there's two males that I noticed, a skinny and a fat guy.   If that's going to offend you you're going to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  The only Muslims in the game are the terrorists/taliban who will attack you on sight, if you're going to be offended, you'll have a problem.  The list goes on.   If you can get offended, this game will try to find that button. But overall, I mean it's insults from 2003, that kind of don't hit any more.  I don't know, I can't really be offended by it, because it's made to offend, not because it's an honest opinion expressing itself. There is a bit of cognitive dissonance when you get to the trophies as they were added recently.   There's numerous references to both the League and It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia as well as other recent pop culture in the trophies.  It's actually a weird touch, but you know what?  It kind of helps. As for the technical parts of the game, the majority of the game works perfectly, with the exception of the sound.  Ugh, the sound.  I'm going to guess this was the beginning of 3d sound technology, and maybe something's changed since then, but the main character speaks VERY loud, and every other important character is near impossible to hear.  A shame.I could go into more, but honestly.  If you want to see what got a lot of people's panties in a bunch in 2003 this is a perfect game for that.  It's not an amazing game, it's not going to blow you away.  This isn't going down in the hall of fame of gaming (except for its attempt at offensiveness) but I've played a lot of worse games, and Postal 2 seems to understand it's not a top tier game and has priced themselves at a realistic number.  Overall there's a game that works well (though I did see a few crashes).  It's both incredibly playable and interactive.  It actually has a lot of choice involved in it (you can beat the game without killing anyone or ignore the story and go on a murder rampage, the game allows both options).  And with the exception of the sound issue that was an annoyance, it's still a solid game. If you're unsure, I would probably not recommend the game, but for what it is, it's a positive gaming experience.  Just be sure you know what you're getting into and aren't going to get offended by 13 year old jokes (that are probably also aimed at 13 year olds)

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Postal 2 is a fantastic example of a do whatever you want sandbox game.  It's also one of the funniest games I've ever played.  Nothing is off limits for Running With Scissors (The guys who made the game).  It's really offensive in so many ways.  Wanna put a cat on the end of your shotgun to use as a silencer?  Go ahead.  Wanna throw pairs of scissors at people?  Why not? Wanna chop somebodys head off and then pee on their corpse?.......Well yeah, you can also do that.  I think everybody can find something in this game that they enjoy.  There are so many weapons and so many movie references that that fill this game that I just couldn't stop playing it till the end.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Postal 2 is one of those games, sick, tasteless, and certainly not afraid to offend people. Postal 2 will definatly be considered a guilty pleasure by many players who enjoy the game. Postal 2 is a PC only game first released in April of 2003 and was developed by Running with Scissors. In Postal 2 you play as the Postal dude, a guy who lives in a caravan with his wife in a city known ironically enough as "Paradise", that's really it as far as story goes, it's pratically non-existant.The game is divided up into 7 days; monday, tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday and Sunday. In each day your objectives are to perform menial tasks such as buying milk, paying your speeding fine, all that kind of stuff. What makes each day interesting though, is that you have the freedom to go through these objectives as you see fit, do you try go through the game not laying harm upon an NPC? Or do you go Postal and kill everyone in your way, or kill as many people as you see fit.If you do go the POSTAL route, there is a large varity of weapons ranging from shovels and mechetes, to M16 rifles and Remington shotguns, Jerry cans and stun guns, hunting rifles and Napalm launchers, the list goes on. If you are unsatisfied of the look of the M4 Carbines and/or Remington shotguns, you can always decorate them by putting a cat silencer onto the barrel.At the end of most menial tasks something can go horribly wrong, such as while confessing your sins at a church, the church will be attacked by terrorists, and you gotta escape avoiding all the enemies, or kill all of them. I gotta say, the hit detection of most of the weapons are sometimes pretty hit-n-miss, for example using the shotgun isn't always an instant kill upon headshot, even at the closest range possible, the same case applys to the hunting rifle, although this issue never became too big or annoying enough to make me quit the game or yell in anger. If you get caught by the police doing things you shouldn't you'll gain a wanted level and you gotta hide to reduce it until it runs out and you're free to roam about again, unless you get arrested in which case you gotta escape from prison, the cool part is that the wanted system also applies to NPCS, so watching other NPCS going postal never gets old.Speaking of a wanted system you can also find a policeman's uniform and become a cop and perform all the crimes you want that aren't against cops.Oh yeah you can pee in this game, I'm not joking, at any moment you can press the R key and start♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on things as much as you please, and if you forget to zip up your pants NPCS will remark at it saying things like "No one's impressed", "I've seen bigger", and "Hey! Mr Peepshow! Put your hands in the air!".Also, I gotta mention the impressive fire system, when you got a Jerry Can, you can pour gasoline and pour pools of the stuff and ignite it when ready, when NPCS walk in the fire, they will often run at other NPCS which will set them on fire, until they turn into a burnt corpse holding on to their life.I gotta say though, the voice acting apart from the Postal dude is just horrendous, all the NPCS sound like they have the same voice just with a different pitch and often talk like this; "Hi, That'll be. 400. Bucks.". The Postal dude, while has some bad lines, still makes up for it by having a sort of personality with many lines, such as "Somebody stole my donut! now you're all gonna pay!".The A.I. is also pretty bad, regularly forgetting to shoot their gun at me and getting in the way a lot.The world itself is very open and you can go anywhere as you see fit as long as the game lets you because some areas are inaccessable until a day such as friday or wednesday, if you're out of money and you don't feel like getting it the legal way, you can always head to the Paradise Bank and go inside the vault and empty it out stealing hundreds of $. You pretty much can do whatever you want at anypoint of the game. Also, 90% of buildings in Postal 2 you can enter, so if you feel like it, you can go around and literally kick open most doors in the game, or if you're too cool to go through the door you can always kick through the windows. Since the world is so open, it encourages a lot of exploration, which rewards explorers with weapons, items, and some secret areas.Soundwise, there isn't really any music in the game aside from some ambiance inside of a store, all the weapons got a nice ring to them, and the voice acting is again terrible.Graphically, the game for it's time looked "okay", by today's standards it definatly look's dated but never really subtracted the experience for me.Also Garry Coleman is in this game, no seriously check it out.Overall, I can't say I can recommend this game to everybody, I mean I've enjoyed it a large amount and I'm glad it focuses more on fun rather than fancy graphics or voice acting, but much of the humor is usually about toilet humor, homosexuals, rednecks, Arab-Terrorists, some sterotypes, animal cruelty that kind of stuff. I mean hell this game is known as one of the most offensive games to come out for a reason which caused it to get outright banned in countries such as Australia and New Zealand. Althought if you can get by the of childish humor, I'm sure you might have a blast with the game, I know I did.Did I mention Uwe Boll made a movie about this game?Postal 2 sure defines the term "Guilty Pleasure"7/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Probably Postal 2 is the only game that was banned in most countries for its gross, abhorrent content. I'll elaborate what this means: you can unzip your pants and pee on all the citizens you encounter, there's animal cruelty, all kinds of racial and ethnic stereotypes you can imagine, there's even vomiting and wherever you go there's a lot of violence.In the game you play as the Dude (cool but not as cool as Big Lebowsky's Dude), a fellow who needs to survive one week. One week in his small town with the general daily tasks such as picking up the hard-earned wages or buying milk or taking back the book to the library. But something always happens: when you go to the church to confess your sins, for example, Arab terrorists attack. The game allows you to go wherever you want and whenever you want: essentially, it feels like a non-linear game. Once you reach your destination a cutscene takes place and you follow a linear path after which you are back in town free to go to the place you desire.The game looks horrendous but it is understandable as it is a more than 10-year old software. Even at the time of its release it looked outdated. Still, it is a fun game and the Steam version comes with expansion packs and achievements. If it is discounted, it is easily the best purchase currently on Steam!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												It's an age old game that's more of insanity bordering on the welcome-to-the-asylum line than anything else. It's what you would expect from a FPS game but at the same time, there are parts of it that I enjoyed more than anything else I've played in a long time. There are still some bugs within the game, despite being out for such a long time. One such bug I encountered was that I cut off both legs from an NPC, she got up and started to run away on invisible legs. If you go to jail, you lose everything; your guns, money, food, anything that's not your matches since you need that to break out of jail. Also, if you catch on fire, pee on yourself to put yourself out. It's not much of a sandbox although you can treat it as one if you disregard the mission that you are currently on sometimes. Other times, the mission does not allow you to freely roam and you must stick to the mission in question. All in all, I do recommend this game.This game truly entertained me for quite a while as I ran around the maps throwing my machete and waiting for it to boomerang back to me. Not only that, I loved going on a rampage and killing everyone with my insane weapons. You could say the same for GTA and Saints Row games but there's just something about peeing on someone, watching them throw up out of disgust, then kicking them until they die. Another entertaining thing to do: throwing a sledgehammer at the♥♥♥♥♥of a cow. Trust me...I spent half an hour doing that until I died from being rammed by the same cow I was ramming.

Or you could simply wax everybody in the store and walk out with a carton of milk and 5 dollars. That being said, (and I must agree with the angry parents) this game is not for children (or easily offended, pansy, liberals.)Silly, violent, funny, quirky, violent, politically topical, and violent; Postal 2 is for the adults who want a sick yet enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												You will find Postal 2 on numerous sites and gaming lists as the most conversial game of all time. I recently obtained a newer PC & after finally getting this game again I can happily say, it has aged gloriously! Postal 2 completely blows it's nose with the first game and it's story and starts something hilarious. While Postal was about the dude going on a city wide killing spree featuring dark psychotic tones, the sequel is the dude just trying to live out a week in his city while dealing with a completely exaggerated but hilarious enviroment. The levels are broken up into days of the week and it's semi free roam, meaning you can go where you want but certain areas don't open up until a later day. The game, at first on the easier difficulties, really is as violent as you are until your forced to deal with one of the many hate groups you encounter over the week. Postal 2 has alot of replay value too, when you beat it you can play through again in Enhanced mode which just makes the game pure gold.The Steam Support for this game is incredible. 68+a few hidden Achievements,Multiplayer,Workshop Support, and Steam Cards. Also comes with a Level Editor!Performance wise the game looks great for being over 10 years old! Win 8.1 No complaints

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Postal 2 is one of my favorite games of all time.There are quite a few misconceptions regarding Postal 2. I've talked to people that have never played the game and they thought all you did in the game was kill people. That is incorrect. Yes, there is pretty much no story, only mundane tasks like cashing in your check from work, and picking up your laundry. A lot of the time, something crazy happens, like while you're cashing in your paycheck, the bank get's robbed and the cops and robbers get into a shootout, or video game conservatives raid the game developer's HQ that you just got fired from. Yes, there are tons of weapons. Yes, the game is VERY gorey. But in a way, Postal 2 is less violent than Grand Theft Auto. Grand Theft Auto has missions that literally tell you to go to X, kill Y. Postal 2 doesn't. It gives you a very large arsonal of weapons, but that's it. They never tell you to USE those weapons."The game is only as violent as you are."Now, onto why this is one of my favorite games of all time...It's bloody fun, no pun intended.There have been days where I have just felt awful. I had a bad day, and just wanted to release some stress. So I'd hop on Postal 2, and go on a murderous rampage. About 30 minutes - an hour later, i'd feel refreshed and in a better mood. This game is the greatest stress ball ever created.The combat is fun, the AI isn't very good, but still serviceable. The enemies range from angry protestors, rednecks, and of course, police.I really like the police in this game. They act like actual police, unlike Grand Theft Auto, where it's more of a parody of police. Also, you have the option to surrendor and get arrested. You are then placed in a cell, with all of your weapons stripped away. You can break out and steal your weapons back.I also really like the map. It's not very big, but certainly not small. Especially considering you only walk in this game, there are no vehicles. You can find some pretty messed up things through out the map. I once found a backyard that had an entire family with their bodies burned to a bloody crisp, with a rotting cow head placed on; what looked like a religous artifact. This game is very bloody and gorey, but you can disable it if it's too intense for you.Running With Scissors earned my respect from this game. They didn't give a damn about political correctness, or what people thought of them and the game. They simply made the game they wanted. While I absolutely love this game, and know a few people that do as well... I also know a few people that despise this game. I really can't recommend this game to everybody. I can see why people would be offended by this game, but just remember... It's a computer game.8.5/10.Boy, why did I write such a long review? No one EVER reads my reviews :\

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												I've always heard a lot about this game, and been intrigued by it due to it's credentials for controversy. Finally decided to buy it and try for myself. I wasn't expecting much in terms of gameplay but am I in for a surprise. 10 years on and I have to say I haven't played a game this fun for a long while. Yes, it's very crude and sets out to offend, and production values are pretty low, but that's actually the point, and in fact where the wacky fun comes in. I don't play video games to be polictically correct!The very wide variety of weapons and items in an open world with plenty of NPC in-fighting allows for creative play which IMHO is unmatched by any game in recent history. The fact that you can wee on yourself to put out a flesh fire is unprecedented (and dare I say, unlikely to be replicated) in gaming history and reason enough to experience this game. They simply don't make games like this anymore. If only someone has the guts to make and, most of all, publish something like this today!

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												First off, this isn't something you want your kid under the age of like 14-15 playing.  This one is for YOU,The original game from 2003 - Postal 2 - based on the Unreal Engine is a satire-laced adventure into the open-world fps genre.  If you like to laugh, like to hunt for secrets (think Doom type secrets), enjoy trying to find 'others ways of doing things', or just wish to blow off steam while getting a good laugh - this game is entirely for you.  Do not hesitate.A few things you can do in this game:Kick or throw cats through a window or use them as a silencerLure cops with donuts (or dress up as one)Lure dogs with dog treats or bags of foodRob the bank (more than one way)Be a pacifist and don't hurt anyone who doesn't try to hurt you.Go on a murderous rampage with any number of over a dozen different weaponsPee on someone and make them barf (or shoot you, or run away)Douse a person or people in gas and well... you know the rest[enhanced game] Give cats catnip, and then pick them back up and then throw them onto someone and they become a taz-style dervish.  Catnip normally just attracts cats in the basic game, or you can smoke it!Find a Chris-Mess tree in July (in Arizona!) for your nagging wife[this next one is for all the guys involved in Operation Iraqi Freedom/Enduring Freedom]Find the secret taliban base and exterminate them and get the WMD!also....Roam around accomplishing nothing but exploration or mayhem ignoring all the mission objectivesBlow off a whole-lotta-steam from a hard days work with a good laugh...this is barely a comprehensive list... many many more things to do, I won't spoil it allBest of all - it runs on even the more basic computers available today!  You don't need an incredibly powerful gaming machine!Seriously - you'll want to try this one.The PARADIS LOST DLC:  GET IT, if you enjoyed the base game, YOU MUST GET IT.  Higher res textures, more detailed level design (duh), new missions.  It's making up for all those years since the Apoc Weekend DLC game out.  So reasonably priced too!Running With Scissors, I cannot thank you enough.  This is awesome.  You don't know the redeeming quality that is massacre-ing a GINGER that loves Chris-Mess.  That aweful holiday rhumba got me in the mood for war quicker than anything!  Peeing on Gingers, Animal Abuse, Impersonating a cop, exploring the run-down mostly abandoned mall, and little monkeys with guns that are half-robot or something.  It's all just so awesome.You keep making DLC's,  I'll keep buying them.  GREAT WORK!  Oh, and if anyone reading this is Irish... no offense, I just happen to have one after me in real life who is trying to illegally track me.  Don't take it to heart unless you're that one person.   This is a well made game through and through, DLC and all, don't pass it up, especially if you have a sense of humor.   Just bring that 320$ for a roll of TP otherwise you'll have to hawk cats for money :)
