content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Postal 2 takes everything you love in video games (like peeing on enemy corpses that you've slaughtered and playing fetch using a severed head with your best friend to name but a few) and integrates it seamlessly in an open-world anarchist humour-fest.Do I pay for things and conform to society? Or do I smash their heads in and get things done however I see fit? Do I set them on fire then proceed to pee on them to extinguish the fire only to stab them repeatedly with a pair of scissors? Do I run and hope for the best or do I shove a shotgun barrel up a kittens sacred region as a make-shift silencer and take everyone out? These are but a few of the vast choices you will be making, and at the end of the day who said anyone had to die? It's all about completing the tasks, whichever way you see fit.While the regular Postal 2 gameplay is quite mellow, if you're looking for serious action (Resident Evil meets Silent Hill) from start till finish that will keep you on the edge of your seat and which resembles more of a quick-paced Half-Life run I'd thoroughly recommend the Apocalypse Weekend mode (after you've completed the main Monday-Friday run of course, to get into the swing of things as Postal 2 isn't your normal shooter and takes a bit of getting used to).All in all, for a game that was released in 2003 (over 10 years ago!) the constant updates (up until this very year, over 10 years later) have only improved the content tenfold, from better graphical support (widescreen now available!) to bug fixes and gameplay improvement you're guaranteed a smooth transition into what is certainly one of the best first person shooters around. Do yourself a favour and give Postal 2 a try, you can't go wrong.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Postal 2 is a game that tried very hard to ensure that if you don't leave completely offended, you will eithera) have a good chuckle and laugh a great deal or,b) see the completely flawed game mechanics and truthfully... abysmal game veiled under some uncreative, yet funny, game comedy.So obviously this game is not for everyone, specifically anyone who is easily offended, by either the ability to urinate as an attack of sorts, maybe the odd run in with drugs as a major health increase, or perhaps the major idea of the game being that life's ultimate short-cut is extrenous violence.But if you can take this game with a good humour, it is a very odd corner of the video game world that should be experienced once in a while.Yes, as a game, its pretty bad, the shooting is clunky, you have many different items in your inventory and yet no real way to easily access them, and the goals are a bit vague and confusing at times, making you guess or give up and drop a few pedestrians and urinate on their corpses.It has a charm though, very quirky, and with a few really interesting points in the days, usually ending in hilarity or a side-ways look of judgement from whomever notices you playing it.If you can get it for around 5 bucks, it can be worth it, but don't expect an award winner.5.4/10

												One of the most fun and addicting games I have ever played. The game has clever, funny satire. It rewards you for exploring, having lots and lots of hidden areas with weapons and health items. I'm still finding new things after well over a dozen playthroughs. It has fun, entertaining tasks to complete. Be it getting milk from a store or committing genocide on an unsuspecting town using shotguns and machineguns fitted with silencers made out of still living cats, Postal 2 will surely provide you with hours upon hours of entertainment.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Go to the shop and buy some milk - How many people will you kill along the way? How many cats will you penetrate? Will you need that chainsaw? Where did you get that severed head? When did you become addicted to crack? These are just some of the questions you'll have to answer in Postal 2.If you've ever wanted to cut someones head off and then urinate on it, guess what? You're NOT alone! In Postal 2 you can meet like minded people, share tips on how best to humilate, abuse, mutilate and cause general suffering to.... Anyone!Personally, I enjoy urinating in someones face untill they start vomiting violently, then I give them a full charge from a tazer and watch them lose control of thier bladder while convulsing on the floor in a puddle of thier own vomit and urine. Then I take a lovely little break, smoke a crack pipe, eat a slice of 'za, maybe even have a doughnut and then it's back to work. I'll take the hedge trimmers I borrowed from a neighbor (after I cut his head off with a machete) and remove thier hands and feet one by one, if they survive that I'll take off thier arms and legs and sometimes, they even survive that, so I'll cut them in half.Once a cop survived! No arms, no legs and cut in half, as his guts slowly started to seep out and he was crying, I thought I better not miss an oppertunity, so I dropped my trousers and bust one out up the wall, when I was done, shame ejected, I covered him in petrol, throw a match on him, and left. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Are you tired of playing as that lone single survivor mowing down legions of moaning zombies with a sawed-off shotgun? Perhaps you're sick of being that dynamic hero who saves the town/planet/universe/whatever from thousands of enemy soldiers/aliens/demons/zombies/whatever? If you said yes to any of these, perhaps maybe you should give Postal 2 a try...quite possibly one of the wackiest and most offensive FPS games out there.The game takes place in a corrupt town called Paradise, where you play as the Postal Dude, a henpecked husband running errands (missions) all over the town for his nagging wife. The game plays on a day-to-day basis (monday through friday for the postal 2 mode, saturday and sunday for apocolapse weekend mode, and all 7 days for the AWP mode), and missions can range from just about everything from picking up your paycheck, getting people to sign your petition and picking up milk. Sounds like nothing could possibly go wrong, right? Well...you'll also encounter plenty of enemies, ranging from crazy cannibal butchers, rampaging rednecks, corrupt cops, the taliban and even violent video game protestors.The game itself is actually very non-linear in design, which is a treat. You can complete the errands you have to do at your own pace to have time to explore your envoirnments to find plenty of weapons and other collectables, or you can simply complete your missions as quickly as you can to beat the game as quickly as possible. Also you can make the game as violent as you want---you can go postal and kill everyone and everything with a variety of different weapons, including gasoline, rocket launchers, firearms, grenades, shovels, knives, and even your own urine...or you can try to be a pacifist and not kill anyone (though it's heavily encouraged at times).In short, this game certainly isn't for everyone: Postal 2 tries really hard to be as offensive as possible, and there's plenty of ridiculously over-the-top violence. However, if you're looking for a unique FPS to play, or simply have a dark sense of humor, Postal 2 is worth a buy...and the $10 price tag is hard to beat. 4.0/5.0

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Now with Steam Workshop support, along with recent patchwork, there's no reason not to go back to this game once more! Honestly, when it came out, it was pretty groundbreaking at the time. In the early-mid 2000's, games were finally able to "let loose" shall we say with regard to more adult content. Postal 2 definitely had a lot of firsts in that regard.While Postal 2 is not as shocking now as it was in the past, it's still the one and only game I've played which allows for the player to urinate on people. When this came out a little over 10 years ago (and granted, I was still in High School then), all someone needed to tell me was that you can♥♥♥♥♥♥on people in this game. It reminded me of when I was a kid in Elementary School, and a friend of mine told me about this new game Duke Nukem 3d (at the time). He told me I could pee in toilets and pay women to show me their boobs; I was sold. This is the kind of thing that will be immediately off-putting to some, while immediately endearing to others. With this kind of game, it's a "love it or hate it" situation. Even when we're older, sometimes it can be nice to just go back and unwind for a bit. We need to experience what it's like to be a kid again in silly ways, and this is definitely one of them.Unfortunately, Postal 3 was a flop, but hey, more reason to go back to this one! If you've never played it, and if absurd, over-the-top, politically incorrect humor sounds appealing to you, go for it! Have a blast with this one, and don't take it (or yourself) too seriously.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Postal 2 is an enjoyable game in which you can carry out the tasks of a week from either Monday to Friday, Monday to Sunday or just the apocalyptic weekend, depending on what mode you play. Despite dated graphics, Postal 2 is definitely a loveable game that allows the player to be as violent as they please. You can even try being completely passive, I'd imagine it's difficult, but they say it's doable. Running With Scissors took a simple idea of doing tasks for your wife and made a game out of it, and did it very well. It is thoroughly enjoyable from start to finish, but I confess I've yet to get my lazy♥♥♥♥♥to play everything again. Regardless, the game is immensly enjoyable for those who like the humor in it and the ever lovable voice of Rick Hunter, as the beloved Postal Dude, really nails his lines in a perfect manner.Even more fun is that you can see the game devs themselves on the first day, and you can pass through their offices on your travels. And as an added bonus, they often aid you in combat. So with a large array of weapons (including the ability to♥♥♥♥♥♥everywhere), you'll find many creative ways to kill enemies, cops or innocent bystanders as you try to make it to the end of each day.I'd recommend buying this game at any price, either full retail or on sale, as it is good fun and the developers deserve whatever you could give. But if you are somewhat easily offended, don't like the violence, don't like dated grahics or you are a plain old buzzkill, don't bother getting it. It wouldn't be for you.Note: a link to my PL review since it doesn't seem to show up properly at the time of posting: http://steamcommunity.com/id/the_boggy_fella/recommended/360960/

content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												What can I say about the game that I have completed over 15 times and I still enjoy playing to this very day?The beauty about Postal 2 is that it gives you a true choice. For example, one of your first errands buying milk can be completed in 3 ways:1) Walk inside the shop, get milk, wait in a line, pay 5$ for it.2) Walk inside the shop, get milk, don't bother waiting in the line and just steal the milk.3) Walk inside the shop, get milk, kill everyone in the shop, get into the back room and steal everything you can.After completing the game, you can replay it. On higher difficulties or with a different play style.There are fun achievements, that actually make you play the game in a different way.There is multilayer and there is a strong modding community that makes awesome maps and mods.And finally. you help making Postal 4 a reality. A true sequel that the fans deserve. Something that RWS will develop in the house and make it even more awesome than Postal 2 (if such a thing is even possible).Do I need to say more?TL;DR Version: Buy it! Or I will follow you home and kill your dog. I'm not kidding. :P

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												I've always heard a lot about this game, and been intrigued by it due to it's credentials for controversy. Finally decided to buy it and try for myself. I wasn't expecting much in terms of gameplay but am I in for a surprise. 10 years on and I have to say I haven't played a game this fun for a long while. Yes, it's very crude and sets out to offend, and production values are pretty low, but that's actually the point, and in fact where the wacky fun comes in. I don't play video games to be polictically correct!The very wide variety of weapons and items in an open world with plenty of NPC in-fighting allows for creative play which IMHO is unmatched by any game in recent history. The fact that you can wee on yourself to put out a flesh fire is unprecedented (and dare I say, unlikely to be replicated) in gaming history and reason enough to experience this game. They simply don't make games like this anymore. If only someone has the guts to make and, most of all, publish something like this today!

You're NOT alone! In Postal 2 you can meet like minded people, share tips on how best to humilate, abuse, mutilate and cause general suffering to.... Anyone!Personally, I enjoy urinating in someones face untill they start vomiting violently, then I give them a full charge from a tazer and watch them lose control of thier bladder while convulsing on the floor in a puddle of thier own vomit and urine. Then I take a lovely little break, smoke a crack pipe, eat a slice of 'za, maybe even have a doughnut and then it's back to work. I'll take the hedge trimmers I borrowed from a neighbor (after I cut his head off with a machete) and remove thier hands and feet one by one, if they survive that I'll take off thier arms and legs and sometimes, they even survive that, so I'll cut them in half.Once a cop survived! No arms, no legs and cut in half, as his guts slowly started to seep out and he was crying, I thought I better not miss an oppertunity, so I dropped my trousers and bust one out up the wall, when I was done, shame ejected, I covered him in petrol, throw a match on him, and left. I had made it to the shop and bought some milk, now I just needed to get home......But that's another story........Postal 2! It's ****ing bat**** crazy! You'd be crazy to not play it! content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Are you tired of playing as that lone single survivor mowing down legions of moaning zombies with a sawed-off shotgun? Perhaps you're sick of being that dynamic hero who saves the town/planet/universe/whatever from thousands of enemy soldiers/aliens/demons/zombies/whatever? If you said yes to any of these, perhaps maybe you should give Postal 2 a try...quite possibly one of the wackiest and most offensive FPS games out there.The game takes place in a corrupt town called Paradise, where you play as the Postal Dude, a henpecked husband running errands (missions) all over the town for his nagging wife. The game plays on a day-to-day basis (monday through friday for the postal 2 mode, saturday and sunday for apocolapse weekend mode, and all 7 days for the AWP mode), and missions can range from just about everything from picking up your paycheck, getting people to sign your petition and picking up milk. Sounds like nothing could possibly go wrong, right? Well...you'll also encounter plenty of enemies, ranging from crazy cannibal butchers, rampaging rednecks, corrupt cops, the taliban and even violent video game protestors.The game itself is actually very non-linear in design, which is a treat. You can complete the errands you have to do at your own pace to have time to explore your envoirnments to find plenty of weapons and other collectables, or you can simply complete your missions as quickly as you can to beat the game as quickly as possible. Also you can make the game as violent as you want---you can go postal and kill everyone and everything with a variety of different weapons, including gasoline, rocket launchers, firearms, grenades, shovels, knives, and even your own urine...or you can try to be a pacifist and not kill anyone (though it's heavily encouraged at times).In short, this game certainly isn't for everyone: Postal 2 tries really hard to be as offensive as possible, and there's plenty of ridiculously over-the-top violence. However, if you're looking for a unique FPS to play, or simply have a dark sense of humor, Postal 2 is worth a buy...and the $10 price tag is hard to beat. 4.0/5.0

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Postal 2 is a legendary game that still manages to hold it's relevancy to this day, which is to say - quite amazing.The defining quality of this game, which made it stand out, is the freedom that it can offer to the player.  All the others FPS games we saw prior to this game did not have such ambitions as to make a game where you can do whatever you want and whenever you want. Even the main quest you can do in whatever order you prefer. But in the slight chance that you like kicking stuff and shooting at it(inluding shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥out of your hand into the face of unsuspecting pedestrians), you might enjoy this game main quest aside.You are not alone in the game. Your buddies, the RWS staff will help you with any problems should they see you struggling, and should you not anger them. The game is very self-aware and offers much satire and social commentary. But all this things aside it is just an enjoyable game. That said, i meant just the regular game. Vanilla game has a conclusion. So i had no idea that players will recieve some kind of expansions down the line. First came Share the Pain. And all this expansion had to offer were online play and some new areas in the game. At the time i had no awareness as to what linux or mac were, so it was literally nothing to me. I did not mind this expansion very much, and online play did not appeal to me as i had the taste of CS, UT and Quake and they are objectively a better online expirience.But then came Apocalypse Weekend. And it was a ♥♥♥♥ing car crash. The game that i loved and that had a conclusion now recieved some half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥cash-grabbing continuation. It was horrible. The freedom that was Postal 2 was gone from this expansion. It added on two new days of awful linear missons, that feel out of touch and unnecessary. You see, this game's reputation is not due to great shooting mechanics, but it's all we got left in this add-on. Additionally in this expansion they ditched the realistic atmosphere in favour of some supernatural elements, which in my opinion belittled the game even more, and contributed to overall 'out of this world' feel. This add-on had no need to exist. And cemented the game into the ocean of mediocrity. Along the line there were this thing called Postal 3. Now, I did not play this game, and being russian myself i feel shame that it exist, so this mention is all i can allow. The news of the development of the new postal 2 DLC, called "Paradise Lost" were surprising and promising. I can't remember any other cases of developers going back to their old product to produce new content(Romero gets a honourable mention, though).  Basically, it's a new Postal 2 game, set after the events of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Apocalypse Weekend, 12 years ago. This DLC is awesome and you definitely should buy it.  It has the gameplay and charm of the original Postal 2 except for few minor details, and it was a pleasure playing it. What i did not like in "Paradise Lost" is the fact that the god awful Apocalypse Weekend was acknowledged as canon. With this, they did bring the supernatural aesthetics to the dlc. I would enjoy the game far more if that wasn't the case.They plug the motion picture 'Postal' in the dlc and convey some kind of pride for it's existence. Look, there is nothing cool about having uwe boll make a movie about your game and it is the lowpoint of the franchise if you ask me. In the end of 'Paradise Lost' they tease us with postal 4(or as i would prefer, the real postal 3). Let us hope that RWS have learnt from their mistakes, and will deliver us good game one more time. I definitely recommend Postal 2 and the DLC even if the game is over 10 years old and the game engine struggles. They even give you a cool metal track for free! So have at it.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Ah postal, One of the most controversial games to be around. I was one of the poeple who originally played this game before it somehow landed in steam. And honestly i'm happy it came to steam more poeple can be exposed to this masterpeice of a game and know the true defenition of a "controversial game". Pros- Open world You can walk freely around the entire map, Well there are "loading zones" but honestly that shouldn't realy be a problemunless you are running this game on a toaster, Alot of hidden stuff you can find, from passage ways to weapon staches.This game is very exploration friendly, the game progresses in days and unlocks more areas for you to explore therefore gives a feeling of progression, can't realy say the same for the expantion pack levels, they are closed off and are only semi open world.-A large Arsenal at your disposalThis game offers a large arsenal for you to carry around to reak mayhem and havic, and the fun part is, YOU CAN CARRY ALL OF THEM AT ONCE, that's right non of that 3-2 slot ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, you can carry an entire arsenal on you, this might not be a huge thing but for me it's fantastic. reminds me of classic games where you could carry all the guns in the game and not have to throw anything away just to pick up another weapon.-ModsBefore this game had hit steam it has a huge amount of mods for it, weapons, maps, and entire game mods like Eternal Damnnation for example, but with the game hitting steam alot of mods that use to work with the game are now broken due to the game being updated and a bit modernized.but nothing to worry about the mod community is large and growing and with the workshop added to postal 2,Alot of mods are at your disposal, it's only a click away.-The Dark HumorThis game had me laughting my♥♥♥♥♥off for hours, i can't remember a moment this game felt dull, from the sterotyped Indian store clirc to the Corrupt police force this game is packed with pop culture refrences and dark humor, hell it even features Gary Coleman for ♥♥♥♥ sake (R.i.P Gary Coleman), definetly somthing to see for yourself--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Cons-EngineFor it's time postal was pretty average but for todays standarts the old unreal engineis not realy fancy and a bit outdated but non the less it had some good touch up work to make itfeel a bit more modern but the core engine is not realy anything new and ground breakingHonestly there is not realy any other cons i could think of this game is just a masterpeice and definetly somthing to cheak out  if you did not play it back in the era it came out in.

												Go to the shop and buy some milk - How many people will you kill along the way? How many cats will you penetrate? Will you need that chainsaw? Where did you get that severed head? When did you become addicted to crack? These are just some of the questions you'll have to answer in Postal 2.If you've ever wanted to cut someones head off and then urinate on it, guess what? You're NOT alone! In Postal 2 you can meet like minded people, share tips on how best to humilate, abuse, mutilate and cause general suffering to.... Anyone!Personally, I enjoy urinating in someones face untill they start vomiting violently, then I give them a full charge from a tazer and watch them lose control of thier bladder while convulsing on the floor in a puddle of thier own vomit and urine. Then I take a lovely little break, smoke a crack pipe, eat a slice of 'za, maybe even have a doughnut and then it's back to work. I'll take the hedge trimmers I borrowed from a neighbor (after I cut his head off with a machete) and remove thier hands and feet one by one, if they survive that I'll take off thier arms and legs and sometimes, they even survive that, so I'll cut them in half.Once a cop survived! No arms, no legs and cut in half, as his guts slowly started to seep out and he was crying, I thought I better not miss an oppertunity, so I dropped my trousers and bust one out up the wall, when I was done, shame ejected, I covered him in petrol, throw a match on him, and left. I had made it to the shop and bought some milk, now I just needed to get home......But that's another story........Postal 2! It's ****ing bat**** crazy! You'd be crazy to not play it! You'd be crazy if you played it! You'd be crazy to listen to me! I'm off my med's! You'd be crazy too if your wife ran away with your grandma! (They didn't make it far though.....) haha, hahaha HAHAHAHhahAHhahHAHhAAAAAAAHHH WHEN DID MY LIFE GO SO WRONG?! WHAT HAPPENED?!? THE LAST THING I REMEMBER IS BUYING SOME GAME ON STEAM! STEAM!! STAY AWAY FROM STEAMMMMMMMM! NO I DON'T WANT TO GO BACK IN THE STRIAGHT JACKET! NO DRUGS! PLEASE, NO NEEDLES! NOOOOOOOO AHHHH NOOOOOOOOO!!!.......zzzzZZZZZZzzzz........zzzzzZZZZZzzzzzz......Postal 2! Where phychos meet in crowded cells!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												This game is...unique in many ways. A little backstory is that when I was little, around 2000-2005, there was an outcry that videogames were too violent. This game pretty much was made to show just how violent things can get in games. Obviously, it's fun because of this. I assume this game received tons of controversy because of it's violent nature. These are the kinds of games that parents and politicians would be disgusted over, but frankly, us gamers don't care at all, because we see it as entertainment, not senseless violence.Now for a review about the game: In the least, this game had it's difficult times, and action-packed times. This game goes day-by-day throughout a week in the life of "Postal Dude" in Paradise, Arizona. Along the way of running errands, and doing things for his Wife, you'll come around to things you'd outta check out. Some including secrets and items, others include brutally murdering a bunch of annoying protesters. Really in the least, violence never felt so good, especially when it's for a good cause, for you of course. There really isn't much to say about this game, other than I bet GTA fans would love this, smaller, less civilized version. One last note, is that I think anyone could enjoy this game, if you like challenges and working towards a goal so that your Wife will not nag you about it. Anyway, it's a good game, and I think you'd like it too.I nominated this game for the "Best Use of a Farm Animal" award in 2016's Steam Awards.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Postal 2 is violent, irreverent, offensive, and immature. It's also one of the most bizarre and fun shooters I've played in years. I mean, what other game allows you to hurl diseased cow heads at terrorists, watch them vomit everywhere, then kick their dead bodies into other people to infect them as well? Not too many, I'd hope.Postal 2's plot is simple - you're the Postal Dude, and you have 3-4 chores you need to take care of each day. Things as simple as returning a library book and collecting your paycheck become insane challenges when certain crazed citizens of Paradise get involved by shooting up your workplace or burning down the library with you inside. The further into your week you go, the more difficult these tasks become. But, they're never too frustrating, as you never really can hit a point where it's impossible to complete a task. Just duck, weave, and snipe out enemies, and you'll be in the clear usually.The weapons of this game are just as crazy as its scenarios. In addition to the usual shotguns, assault rifles, and pistols, you get weapons like throwable scissors, scythes, sledgehammers, deodorant flamethrowers, and WMD's. They all shine in their own unique ways, and contribute to the surreal atmosphere of the game.While the Apocalypse Weekend expansion might be less enjoyable than the base game, the overall package is worth a play if you enjoyed the first five days of gameplay. I would highly recommend Postal 2 to shooter fans and avid gamers alike. It's just too oddball to pass up.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												This game is...unique in many ways. A little backstory is that when I was little, around 2000-2005, there was an outcry that videogames were too violent. This game pretty much was made to show just how violent things can get in games. Obviously, it's fun because of this. I assume this game received tons of controversy because of it's violent nature. These are the kinds of games that parents and politicians would be disgusted over, but frankly, us gamers don't care at all, because we see it as entertainment, not senseless violence.Now for a review about the game: In the least, this game had it's difficult times, and action-packed times. This game goes day-by-day throughout a week in the life of "Postal Dude" in Paradise, Arizona. Along the way of running errands, and doing things for his Wife, you'll come around to things you'd outta check out. Some including secrets and items, others include brutally murdering a bunch of annoying protesters. Really in the least, violence never felt so good, especially when it's for a good cause, for you of course. There really isn't much to say about this game, other than I bet GTA fans would love this, smaller, less civilized version. One last note, is that I think anyone could enjoy this game, if you like challenges and working towards a goal so that your Wife will not nag you about it. Anyway, it's a good game, and I think you'd like it too.I nominated this game for the "Best Use of a Farm Animal" award in 2016's Steam Awards.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Postal 2 is essentially a VERY watered-down GTA-esque game with the same juvenile humor and open-world style where you're allowed to either cause chaos in killing sprees or pursue a number of missions. Postal 2's missions are simply the protagonist ("Postal Dude") completing a number of menial and trivial tasks (picking up groceries, going to the Bank, etc.) while occasionally being pitted against various enemies (like protesters who believe video-games cause violence - only to whip out automatic rifles and begin indiscriminately murdering people, a group of Jihad leading an assault on a church, etc.) In regards to gameplay, unlike in GTA, you're placed in a relatively rural environment, and there's an odd complete absence of vehicles, except for those in parking - not even NPCs drive any vehicles. Most weapons are found through stealing or finding them, though there some of them are purchasable via the mall.In summary, if you happen to find this game for a good price (like I did, at $2), it's well worth the purchase for several hours of mindless indulgence.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Postal 2 is an open world first person shooter. Calling it a first person shooter is at least the most fitting term for the game since although it features a lot of melee weapons and can even be finished without shooting at all - at least on lower difficulty settings. It is very different from the first Postal game which was a rather dark top down shooter that was broken  up into various levels where the sole objective was to take out all opponents.Postal 2 takes place in a small town called "Paradise". You play as Postal Dude (that is his actual name, I swear) who lives in a trailer with his wife and his dog. He is rather unsatisfied with his current life. He is completely broke, he is the only person in the neighborhood who lives in a trailer, his wife constantly yells at him, his car barely works anymore. He just started at a new job in games development (guess which company) though. Will that help him to get his life back in order?The gameplay of Postal 2 is split up into five days, starting on Monday. Every day Postal Dude gets a number of tasks that must be completed to proceed to the next day. Many tasks are given by his wife but some are his own decision. A majority of the task are rather mundane, for example cashing in your paycheck, buying milk, getting a christmas tree or buying meat for a barbeque or going to your uncle Dave's birthday party. While none of this sound like a pretty exciting  activity the town of Paradise is full of people who would go ballistic over the most trivial things. So even the most mundane task may end up with Postal Dude either running for his life or being forced to kill everybody in the vicinity. At the beginning of the game you just have to be aware of random people starting fights but every day after completing certain quests Postal Dude gets an additional group of enemies who hate his guts so much that they would attack him on sight without thinking twice. Luckily the law enforcement is just as violent as the other citizens and might be a great ally in cases like that. If you start funny business yourself however they will not hesitate shooting you either. You can tackle all tasks at your own pace and explore the town. Exploration is really rewarding since you might find weapons and items that would not be available yet otherwise and might give you a real edge over your enemies. Also, there are small eastereggs jokes and references hidden all over the place.While the first Postal game featured rather dark themes Postal 2 is full of silly over the top humour. Also it might be the most offensive game ever created. The game depicts various groups of society as exaggerated stereotypical caricatures: Censorship advocates, Christians, Muslims, gays, bankers, animal rights activists, policemen, New Age religions - nobody leaves unscathed. (I will tell you a little secret: You can lure policemen by dropping a donut on the ground.) If I needed to compare the humour of Postal 2 to anything I would probably say South Park.On his quest to survive the week Postal Dude can rely on a huge arsenal of tools and weapons. Melee weapons like tasers, shovels, scythe, machetes or sledgehammers as well as ranged weapons like scissors, pistols, shotguns, napalm launchers, rocket launchers, grenades, infectious cow heads (which spread an unpleasant disease) and molotov cocktails. On top of that you can just kick people. There's another "weapon" in Postal Dude's arsenal that should not be left unmentioned: Pee. He can open his pants and just let go. It does not deal any damage but it can stun people briefly if you hit them right in the face. Also, it causes people to either scream at you, flee, attack you or just puke. While this sounds like nothing than an easteregg peeing can be vital to your survival. Fire based weapons are extremely dangerous and when you ever find yourself being on fire you better pee straight up in the air so you can extinguish the flames. It can also be used to clear flames blocking your path or to extinguish burning people other than yourself.As mentioned before there are various tools and items to utilize. Dog biscuits can be used to befriend dogs and make them follow you around. Catnip can NOT be used to befriend cats. Instead you can consume it yourself to slow down the world around you. Cats however can be picked up and either be used as erratic tornadoes of fur and claws (keep your distance) or as silencers to put on your shotgun or assault rifle. A fishing radar comes in handy to show you the position of nearby enemies. Also there are various items that restore health like donuts, pizza or "Health Pipes" - be warned though, they are addictive.There is one gripe I have with the game. Some weapons feel really underwhelming. There is basically no point to some of the melee weapons (for example the shovel) as soon as you found a higher tier one. Also the standard shotgun and assault rifle feel to weak.The town of Paradise feels incredibly alive. Bystanders will walk around the place, talk to each other and either go their merry way or start a fight. If they see corpses they will run away or start vomiting. If they see you in an embarassing situation they will laugh at you. Also, it is entirely possible that huge fights break out without the player having done anything to cause them. Considering when the game came out this is impressively done and really conveys what kind of town we are talking about here. The title Postal does not need to refer solely to the main character but can also be seen as representative of Paradise and its citizens. Postal Dude would have all reason to give up and despair but he rather reacts with snarky sarcasm which makes him kind of likeable. I he goes postal eventually depends on the player but believe me, this town will put your patience to a test.This re-released version of Postal 2 comes with the add-on Apocalypse Weekend that covers Saturday and Sunday. The playstyle is a little different though. Apokalypse Weekend still has the humour of the base game as well as some really neat new ideas and mechanics. Sadly it drops the open world exploration aspect completely and often comes down to tunnel shooter levels and arena fights. It is also a problem that the two most "standard shooter like" levels are among the longest of the expansion. Do not get me wrong though. It is well worth playing, I just feel that it cannot hold a candle to the base game.For the re-release of Postal 2 the developers added several weapons, mechanics and cosmetic tweaks. Some of those had been featured before in community made mods. The developers really went and asked the modders if they were okay with the mods being included in the main game. That's what I call being in touch with the fans.Also, after the re-release being financially quite successful the developers decided that they could afford to work on a second expansion pack for Postal 2 which is by now released and available as DLC. As far as I know releasing an official expansion ten years after the base game came out is completely unheard of. If this doesn't proof incredible dedication to the fanbase I do not what does.What's more, the expansion called Paradise Lost is much closer to the base game than Apocalypse Weekend was. It also features additional content and improvements some of which have been retroactively added to the base game.Long story short if you have not played Postal 2 yet you should give this classic a try. If the humour is not for you or you are easily offended you might not like it. Otherwise it is well worth your time. If you have played Postal 2 before and liked it you should also pick this version up since it is a step up from the original version in every area.More reviews here

content:
Posted: February 15
												In Postal 2, you are tasked with doing errands from your hateful wife. Simple tasks like getting milk, voting and getting Gary Coleman's autograph. What could go wrong? Well a lot of things can go wrong. Without spoiling everything, lets just say a simple trip to the store can turn into a shootout between you and Hijab wearing women.The tagline to Postal 2 is: "It's only as violent as you are". Which is true. Will you lose patience at a line to the bank and end up killing everyone? Or will you wait in line like a civilised person? The choice is yours! Postal 2 is also quite hilarious. You'll ecounter gimps, rednecks, Al-Qaeda and marching bands.I would 100% recommend this game, for those who enjoy violence and dark humor.

												A cult classic with one of the best independent developers supporting it more than 10 years later. It's an open-world FPS that has actually aged well. The Postal Dude is one of the most underrated FPS protagonists ever made. Transitions after walking through one part of Paradise are the only thing that holds this game back for me, but this fault is overridden by the fact that I can urinate on everything. Even though the shock value has evaporated from this title, the fun factor from being able to kill everything that moves is what's left, which is a great thing. Get this♥♥♥♥♥♥as soon as you can.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Postal 2 is an enjoyable game in which you can carry out the tasks of a week from either Monday to Friday, Monday to Sunday or just the apocalyptic weekend, depending on what mode you play. Despite dated graphics, Postal 2 is definitely a loveable game that allows the player to be as violent as they please. You can even try being completely passive, I'd imagine it's difficult, but they say it's doable. Running With Scissors took a simple idea of doing tasks for your wife and made a game out of it, and did it very well. It is thoroughly enjoyable from start to finish, but I confess I've yet to get my lazy♥♥♥♥♥to play everything again. Regardless, the game is immensly enjoyable for those who like the humor in it and the ever lovable voice of Rick Hunter, as the beloved Postal Dude, really nails his lines in a perfect manner.Even more fun is that you can see the game devs themselves on the first day, and you can pass through their offices on your travels. And as an added bonus, they often aid you in combat. So with a large array of weapons (including the ability to♥♥♥♥♥♥everywhere), you'll find many creative ways to kill enemies, cops or innocent bystanders as you try to make it to the end of each day.I'd recommend buying this game at any price, either full retail or on sale, as it is good fun and the developers deserve whatever you could give. But if you are somewhat easily offended, don't like the violence, don't like dated grahics or you are a plain old buzzkill, don't bother getting it. It wouldn't be for you.Note: a link to my PL review since it doesn't seem to show up properly at the time of posting: http://steamcommunity.com/id/the_boggy_fella/recommended/360960/

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Postal 2 is an open world first person shooter. Calling it a first person shooter is at least the most fitting term for the game since although it features a lot of melee weapons and can even be finished without shooting at all - at least on lower difficulty settings. It is very different from the first Postal game which was a rather dark top down shooter that was broken  up into various levels where the sole objective was to take out all opponents.Postal 2 takes place in a small town called "Paradise". You play as Postal Dude (that is his actual name, I swear) who lives in a trailer with his wife and his dog. He is rather unsatisfied with his current life. He is completely broke, he is the only person in the neighborhood who lives in a trailer, his wife constantly yells at him, his car barely works anymore. He just started at a new job in games development (guess which company) though. Will that help him to get his life back in order?The gameplay of Postal 2 is split up into five days, starting on Monday. Every day Postal Dude gets a number of tasks that must be completed to proceed to the next day. Many tasks are given by his wife but some are his own decision. A majority of the task are rather mundane, for example cashing in your paycheck, buying milk, getting a christmas tree or buying meat for a barbeque or going to your uncle Dave's birthday party. While none of this sound like a pretty exciting  activity the town of Paradise is full of people who would go ballistic over the most trivial things. So even the most mundane task may end up with Postal Dude either running for his life or being forced to kill everybody in the vicinity. At the beginning of the game you just have to be aware of random people starting fights but every day after completing certain quests Postal Dude gets an additional group of enemies who hate his guts so much that they would attack him on sight without thinking twice. Luckily the law enforcement is just as violent as the other citizens and might be a great ally in cases like that. If you start funny business yourself however they will not hesitate shooting you either. You can tackle all tasks at your own pace and explore the town. Exploration is really rewarding since you might find weapons and items that would not be available yet otherwise and might give you a real edge over your enemies. Also, there are small eastereggs jokes and references hidden all over the place.While the first Postal game featured rather dark themes Postal 2 is full of silly over the top humour. Also it might be the most offensive game ever created. The game depicts various groups of society as exaggerated stereotypical caricatures: Censorship advocates, Christians, Muslims, gays, bankers, animal rights activists, policemen, New Age religions - nobody leaves unscathed. (I will tell you a little secret: You can lure policemen by dropping a donut on the ground.) If I needed to compare the humour of Postal 2 to anything I would probably say South Park.On his quest to survive the week Postal Dude can rely on a huge arsenal of tools and weapons. Melee weapons like tasers, shovels, scythe, machetes or sledgehammers as well as ranged weapons like scissors, pistols, shotguns, napalm launchers, rocket launchers, grenades, infectious cow heads (which spread an unpleasant disease) and molotov cocktails. On top of that you can just kick people. There's another "weapon" in Postal Dude's arsenal that should not be left unmentioned: Pee. He can open his pants and just let go. It does not deal any damage but it can stun people briefly if you hit them right in the face. Also, it causes people to either scream at you, flee, attack you or just puke. While this sounds like nothing than an easteregg peeing can be vital to your survival. Fire based weapons are extremely dangerous and when you ever find yourself being on fire you better pee straight up in the air so you can extinguish the flames. It can also be used to clear flames blocking your path or to extinguish burning people other than yourself.As mentioned before there are various tools and items to utilize. Dog biscuits can be used to befriend dogs and make them follow you around. Catnip can NOT be used to befriend cats. Instead you can consume it yourself to slow down the world around you. Cats however can be picked up and either be used as erratic tornadoes of fur and claws (keep your distance) or as silencers to put on your shotgun or assault rifle. A fishing radar comes in handy to show you the position of nearby enemies. Also there are various items that restore health like donuts, pizza or "Health Pipes" - be warned though, they are addictive.There is one gripe I have with the game. Some weapons feel really underwhelming. There is basically no point to some of the melee weapons (for example the shovel) as soon as you found a higher tier one. Also the standard shotgun and assault rifle feel to weak.The town of Paradise feels incredibly alive. Bystanders will walk around the place, talk to each other and either go their merry way or start a fight. If they see corpses they will run away or start vomiting. If they see you in an embarassing situation they will laugh at you. Also, it is entirely possible that huge fights break out without the player having done anything to cause them. Considering when the game came out this is impressively done and really conveys what kind of town we are talking about here. The title Postal does not need to refer solely to the main character but can also be seen as representative of Paradise and its citizens. Postal Dude would have all reason to give up and despair but he rather reacts with snarky sarcasm which makes him kind of likeable. I he goes postal eventually depends on the player but believe me, this town will put your patience to a test.This re-released version of Postal 2 comes with the add-on Apocalypse Weekend that covers Saturday and Sunday. The playstyle is a little different though. Apokalypse Weekend still has the humour of the base game as well as some really neat new ideas and mechanics. Sadly it drops the open world exploration aspect completely and often comes down to tunnel shooter levels and arena fights. It is also a problem that the two most "standard shooter like" levels are among the longest of the expansion. Do not get me wrong though. It is well worth playing, I just feel that it cannot hold a candle to the base game.For the re-release of Postal 2 the developers added several weapons, mechanics and cosmetic tweaks. Some of those had been featured before in community made mods. The developers really went and asked the modders if they were okay with the mods being included in the main game. That's what I call being in touch with the fans.Also, after the re-release being financially quite successful the developers decided that they could afford to work on a second expansion pack for Postal 2 which is by now released and available as DLC. As far as I know releasing an official expansion ten years after the base game came out is completely unheard of. If this doesn't proof incredible dedication to the fanbase I do not what does.What's more, the expansion called Paradise Lost is much closer to the base game than Apocalypse Weekend was. It also features additional content and improvements some of which have been retroactively added to the base game.Long story short if you have not played Postal 2 yet you should give this classic a try. If the humour is not for you or you are easily offended you might not like it. Otherwise it is well worth your time. If you have played Postal 2 before and liked it you should also pick this version up since it is a step up from the original version in every area.More reviews here

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Postal 2 is essentially a VERY watered-down GTA-esque game with the same juvenile humor and open-world style where you're allowed to either cause chaos in killing sprees or pursue a number of missions. Postal 2's missions are simply the protagonist ("Postal Dude") completing a number of menial and trivial tasks (picking up groceries, going to the Bank, etc.) while occasionally being pitted against various enemies (like protesters who believe video-games cause violence - only to whip out automatic rifles and begin indiscriminately murdering people, a group of Jihad leading an assault on a church, etc.) In regards to gameplay, unlike in GTA, you're placed in a relatively rural environment, and there's an odd complete absence of vehicles, except for those in parking - not even NPCs drive any vehicles. Most weapons are found through stealing or finding them, though there some of them are purchasable via the mall.In summary, if you happen to find this game for a good price (like I did, at $2), it's well worth the purchase for several hours of mindless indulgence.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Postal 2 is a legendary game that still manages to hold it's relevancy to this day, which is to say - quite amazing.The defining quality of this game, which made it stand out, is the freedom that it can offer to the player.  All the others FPS games we saw prior to this game did not have such ambitions as to make a game where you can do whatever you want and whenever you want. Even the main quest you can do in whatever order you prefer. But in the slight chance that you like kicking stuff and shooting at it(inluding shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥out of your hand into the face of unsuspecting pedestrians), you might enjoy this game main quest aside.You are not alone in the game. Your buddies, the RWS staff will help you with any problems should they see you struggling, and should you not anger them. The game is very self-aware and offers much satire and social commentary. But all this things aside it is just an enjoyable game. That said, i meant just the regular game. Vanilla game has a conclusion. So i had no idea that players will recieve some kind of expansions down the line. First came Share the Pain. And all this expansion had to offer were online play and some new areas in the game. At the time i had no awareness as to what linux or mac were, so it was literally nothing to me. I did not mind this expansion very much, and online play did not appeal to me as i had the taste of CS, UT and Quake and they are objectively a better online expirience.But then came Apocalypse Weekend. And it was a ♥♥♥♥ing car crash. The game that i loved and that had a conclusion now recieved some half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥cash-grabbing continuation. It was horrible. The freedom that was Postal 2 was gone from this expansion. It added on two new days of awful linear missons, that feel out of touch and unnecessary. You see, this game's reputation is not due to great shooting mechanics, but it's all we got left in this add-on. Additionally in this expansion they ditched the realistic atmosphere in favour of some supernatural elements, which in my opinion belittled the game even more, and contributed to overall 'out of this world' feel. This add-on had no need to exist. And cemented the game into the ocean of mediocrity. Along the line there were this thing called Postal 3. Now, I did not play this game, and being russian myself i feel shame that it exist, so this mention is all i can allow. The news of the development of the new postal 2 DLC, called "Paradise Lost" were surprising and promising. I can't remember any other cases of developers going back to their old product to produce new content(Romero gets a honourable mention, though).  Basically, it's a new Postal 2 game, set after the events of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Apocalypse Weekend, 12 years ago. This DLC is awesome and you definitely should buy it.  It has the gameplay and charm of the original Postal 2 except for few minor details, and it was a pleasure playing it. What i did not like in "Paradise Lost" is the fact that the god awful Apocalypse Weekend was acknowledged as canon. With this, they did bring the supernatural aesthetics to the dlc. I would enjoy the game far more if that wasn't the case.They plug the motion picture 'Postal' in the dlc and convey some kind of pride for it's existence. Look, there is nothing cool about having uwe boll make a movie about your game and it is the lowpoint of the franchise if you ask me. In the end of 'Paradise Lost' they tease us with postal 4(or as i would prefer, the real postal 3). Let us hope that RWS have learnt from their mistakes, and will deliver us good game one more time. I definitely recommend Postal 2 and the DLC even if the game is over 10 years old and the game engine struggles. They even give you a cool metal track for free! So have at it.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Ok, I have to admit that this is one of the best video games I have ever played in my entire life. People who never played GTA before (like me) would totally get a kick out of this game.Despite its many difficulty options, POSTAL 2 is a very easy game in my opinion. Only some bystanders have weapons, and the police officers just try to arrest you for no reason! But hey, you play as the Postal Dude, an ordinary guy who just wants to finish his errands and go home, But in the eyes of Paradise's citizens,  they see the Dude as a no good smartass Hitler type tyrant. Well, thats kind of true, if you played the original POSTAL game from 1997 and witnessed how he noticed HE was a bleedin' killer himself, andhe didn't care!What I really like about this game is that it's very GTA like and realistic. You can explore the open world of Paradise, and if you have any maps installed, you can explore those too. You can get suited up with guns and♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrorizing the citizens and fighting the cops and trying to gey the hilarious toy character Krotchy down. And once you finish the game (the original game, not counting Apocalypse Weekend), you unlock cheats, and you can turn bystanders into Gary Colemans or Osamas, or load yoursef up with guns and an unlimited supply of ammo, and even get bonus health stuff whenever you want!And I wanna say the funniest thing about POSTAL 2 is that you can♥♥♥♥♥♥on people, and during the petition mission I asked a bystander to sign it and they said no nd I coaxed them three times, still said np and tats when as punishment, I made their day. I peed on them :D100000000/10 Would♥♥♥♥♥♥on Gary Coleman again

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												Are you too poor for Grand Theft Auto? Do you want a game that the developers still care deeply for even though its been out for a decade? This is the game thats for you. POSTAL 2 is like a christmas present, as you'll never know whats in it. POSTAL 2 has spit in the face of radical muslims, scared parents, tree huggers, its own developers, christians, rednecks, and Gary Colemon, without a care in the world and it manages to hold a great amount respect from fans. If these reasons aren't enough to buy it, here are some more reasons.The gameplay is like a FP GTA, except everyone either walks past you, or charges at you with a sign. However, you can stop them with weapons ranging to a nuke launcher to your own♥♥♥♥♥♥ The sound is still a charm, even though there is barely any music its fun to listen to the protagionists remarks. The graphics are from 2003, so you can't really judge it. Replayability for this game is gigantic, as almost everything in game can be done differently.The most important thing about it is that the developers still care about. If a decade old game still gets updates, I think it is worth your money to buy this game.9/10

												I got this game on sale for two bucks, and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥was it worth it. If you get past the dated graphics there are some really fun moments to be had. Its humor is that of south park, over the top and as disgustingly gory and nasty as possible. For example, I cut off the arms and legs of a cop, as she tried to crawl away I♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on her and set her on fire. With the Postal Dude's hilarious commentary and the ridiculous weaponry, you will be laughing your head off as you decapitate, gib, and burn your way through PETA the Taliban and a variety of other hate groups.

												Ugly textures.Ugly animations.Ugly gameplay.Small map.Fu**** up sh**.But still a good game anyway, nothing great, let's be honest, this is far away to be even a decent game but it is still kind of fun to play and to fu** **** up If the gameplay was better, of course, it would be better, the textures and the graphics could use some adjustments, graphics aren't important, but oh God they're ugly and most of them are glitched and so are the animations.For example, you look into the mirror, you'll see that it is handling his weapon or item differently than it is in first person.Some textures are just passing through (meshes and textures problems).But anyway, it is still fun when you have nothing better to do with your time.6/10  The first one is still far better in my opinion.But hey, it's a game that everyone should try at least once, because, it's an experience, it's just that kind of special.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												It's really a strange game... it certainly isn't a bad game, in fact, I highly reccomend it, it's just a weird approach to a first-person shooter.  It potrays a modern society being corrupt and you play as a social justice warrior... who also seems to be subject to the corruption.  It's kind of twisted, it brings a new concept that I think other games should model off of, and it adds a needed comedic element which really seals this game's good rating.  I'd say 9/10.  Very unusual.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												-Game updates don't kill the game-This is a game launched in 2003, the year a fair amount of steam users were born in, and it is still updated regularly-Funny as hell-Entertaining-Anti PC and SJW-When on sale probably costs less than your lunch at school/college-Quality expansion pack which is also cheap as chips-Even the disappointing Apocalypse weekend expansion is entertaining-Can be mind-numbingly easy or straight from Satan's brain, lots of difficulties10/10Genuinely one of the best games on Steam, no broken settings, no poor optimisation, no controversy (kinda) and is just bloody good. In fact, for those reasons it may be the best game I've ever bought, when I think about it.All for less than £1 on sale.

content:
Posted: March 4
												This is a weird game to make a review about. The game itself is kind of an oddity and if you can describe it as something, it sure as f#ck it would be "complete offensive clusterf#ck". That being said, it's satiric style does make it remarcably fun to play with from time to time, something I wasn't expecting at all. I met this game for the first time with a free demo a f#ckload of years ago and all I remember about it is shooting islamic people with a shotgun that had a cat as a silencer (by literally sticking the poor cat's #sshole on the gun's barrel) and then♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on their corpses. It's that kind of game. As usual I will first talk about it's negative parts, then move up from there.First and foremost, it's biggest problem is the engine and it's gameplay. Saying that it hasn't aged well is putting it lightly. At times weapons just seem to not be worth a damn while NPC's seem to enjoy glitching around and doing one of the worst jobs at actually putting up a fight. There's also glitches, though you'll be glad to know that the Developers STILL try to fix anything gamebreaking that might happen, which is honestly impressive taking into account how f#cking old this game is already. The weapons themselves are a bit dumb. You see, to the end of the game you'll have so many that's just overwhelming at times to go through the damn menu and try to find the one you wanted to use. Specially melee weapons, 90% of them become instantly obsolete later on and they'll just be taking a space in your insanely big inventory. Then there's weapons that just don't have much of an use, like the rocket launcher or grenade launcher that I used around once or twice in the entire thing. Also, this game manages to make shotguns boring. HOW. HOW THE F#CK YOU DO THAT!? THE SHOTGUN IS AS WORTHLESS AS A SILENCER ON A NUKE. Something that's probably obvious by now is that the game is also quite violent and offensive. I know that will turn down a lot of people, so that's my warning. I'll say though, the first POSTAL game was WAAAAY more violent and it actually took itself more seriously, while this one is more of a satirical experience with tons of dumb jokes. You might get a laugh at this one at times mainly because of how insane most stuff is, but sure as hell when racist, sexist or homophobic stuff goes around it drops the ball too much, going from satirically hilarious to just going too far.I'm also not the biggest fan of how much damage you can take and how little there is on the way of healing. All of those food items you might find? Kinda worthless until you have around 50 of them. You better stock up on weed during the early game because it's pretty much what will keep you alive later on, even if it does have a negative side-effect.Lastly, I found the last parts of the game underwhelming compared with the crazy bullsh#t that was happening early. Honestly, it feels like some fans made up the end game based on some dude's fanfiction; it's close to what you would expect, but it's just not the same.Is the game good, though? In a cosmic sort of way, yes.You see, this is one of those games that are so ungodly f#cking bad that they're actually amazing. Pretty much EVERYTHING in the game is SO WRONG that it's good. Just think of Hatred, one of the edgiest games out there, actually done well. It manages to be fun for a long amount of time despire it's issues and that's not something you pull off easily.The game also gives you a ton of freedom on doing the main objectives however you feel like, which is something I honestly love. It does drop the ball with the freedom later on, but oh well. I'd also say that actually playing the game on a pacifistic respectful way is just as hilariously fun as the psycopathic trigger-happy one.The main character also has a pretty cool voice-actor behind him and I actually enjoyed his performance and ironic, sarcastic bullsh#t. Just think of a young Duke Nukem who had enough with planet Earth and feels like going on a rampage and it's nearly as fun as the actual Duke.The story itself is also cool enough for a game like this. Sure there isn't much, but I don't think this game needed more. It's simple, and it stays simple until said late-game stages were it kinda drops the ball. Do I recommend this game? It mainly drops down to your tolerance to over-the-top offensive♥♥♥♥♥♥ If you can handle those kind of things, then you'll find a game that's fun as hell for all the wrong reasons and that despite having sh#t FPS mechanics, it's still worth going through to the end. If you can't take a joke, turn back right now. I don't think this game is best suited for you.TL;DR Edition: One of the most offensive games you can find lately, which plays like out-of-date sh#t and it still manages to be fun. You should be wary of it's extremely offensive nature before you buy it, but once you do you'll find that the game is actually just satirical and poking fun at it. Maybe poking fun a bit too hard, but I'd still recommend it on a Steam sale if you can take a f#cking joke.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Amazing game where zero ♥♥♥♥s are given!  You get different assignments everyday that you must accomplish.  Very great combat for first person shooter with a variety of weird guns.  Cats are used for silencers on the shotgun and M4A4.  The tasks get stranger as you go becoming more difficult as well.  Great game if you like to destroy lots of things and carry on rampages with people.  For example you can pee on yourself if on fire or on others to annoy them!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Postal 2 is an experience unlike any I have ever had, peeing on yourself to turn off a fire you started with your gasoline canister, stick cats on shutguns via their arses to silience the shotgun, stirring the taliban in their quick-e-mart stronghold, or snatching the last crotchy at the mall only to uncover saddistic dog/cat experiments in the same mall. Its a free roam world that does great things with a map and some daily quests. Try the catnip, fight the law, put out people on fire with your own♥♥♥♥♥♥ Life is great in Paradise, a desert community filled with angry video game protestors, postal postmen/women. Find hidden weapons, secret paths, play with a variety of great weapons to use like the heat seaking rocket launcher and the brutal diseased cow head. With an assortment of ranged and melee weapons. Gets progresively harder as more days go by, and can be very punishing at higher difficult levels. Stealth works in your favor as you clear the many "important" tasks that you recieve on a daily basis. With awesome power-ups like the fish finder and dressing up as a cop to avoid them, this game has alot of content packed-in. Great physics for its time and ragdolling heads with your kick ability is great. A true classic to its genre. I fully recommend giving Postal 2 a try, avoid postal 3 and postal 1 is ok but not as great as this one is. Cheers!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Postal 2 is really quite an unique game, though uniqueness never garantees quality. at it's best, it is a rather cynical and blundering parody of video game violence, in similar vein to games like Harvester. but at it's worst it's a very mediocure first-person shooter ladened with bugs and poor design choices. there are a few good points however: the town you get to wander around is suprisingly detailed and can be quite enjoyable to explore and find secrets in. the NPC interaction is, while very awkward and disjointed, quite enthralling taking into account the time of the game's release. however, It's pretty hard to reccomend as an actual game, because once the novelty of being able to pour gasoline on a cat, set it ablaze with a match and then♥♥♥♥♥♥on it's charred gory carcass wears off, you then see for what the game really is: an abhorrent mess of offensive stereotypes and gratuitous violence. but I can recommend this game for the experience it offers. you may get more out of it that way. I would suggest going in not expecting much, you may be pleasently suprised... note the word MAY.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												I’ve got two words for you: Anger Management. Theres always those few times where you’re ready to explode and do something stupid, but this is the real world. You know that doing that one stupid thing will probably follow you around your whole life. How about instead of doing that stupid thing in real life, DO IT IN A VIDEO GAME!Postal 2 by Running With Scissors is the perfect game to do it with given that the main focus of the game is pretty much brutal murder in the most obscene ways.Running on the Unreal 2 engine, postal 2 may not look pretty, but don’t let that stop you from enjoying the utter mindlessness of the game. You play as Postal Dude (no really that’s his actual name “Postal Dude”) who is an angry redhead in a trenchcoat and sunglasses just trying to live a peaceful life in the fictional town of Paradise, although, he is given a set of simple tasks for 5 days.This game can be played two ways: Murdering everyone you see because why the hell not, or not killing or harming a single person (no matter what happens to you), however the developers throw your way a series of increasing annoyances such as long lines at a bank, having to pay postage fees, getting gonorrhea (that actually happens), and the parents against violent games committee ironically pulling firearms and attempting to shoot you on sight.The game is INCREDIBLY obscene and racist. There are the stereotypical turbin wearing terrorists running about and they make their hideout in a convenience store named “The Lucky Ganesh” while you try to go pick up “Jihad brand goat milk” (i’m not ♥♥♥♥ing kidding here). Gary Coleman also makes an appearance as a short, high voiced dwarf. There is a series of toys called the “Bad Touch Crotchy” which… obviously… is a scrotum with a smiley face on it. I could go on with this game’s incredibly offensive content, but I won’t.Postal 2 is a great way to relieve stress and have fun, but if you’re sensitive to incredible amounts of offensive content, this is NOT THE GAME FOR YOU. The complete package is available on steam for 9.99pros:- fun gameplay-surprisingly hard- stress relievercons:-unessecary racism7/10 (just because of the racism)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												Postal 2 is unique. It absolutely lacks a coherent story, but for what it lacks in narrative it makes up in playability. The game is absolutely insane, for example: I was exploring the local sewer system behind the protagonists house with a shotgun stuck up a local cat's♥♥♥♥♥♥ when I happened upon a Taliban insurgence base where I proceded to murder them with said cat♥♥♥♥♥♥gun, and then I killed their leader with a severed cow head. None of this had anything to do with the story. It has a hit and miss sense of humor, and it is normally racial, childish or shock style of humor and caters to the lowest class of intelligence. I almost never laughed at the dialogue; not because I was offended, but because most of the time it just was not very funny. The game is offensive though and if that is ever taken in to account when making a purchase do not buy this game. The best humor in this game is simply when you create over-the-top murder situations, like butchering the entire town with a limb hacking machete while pretending you are Jason Vorhees. The graphics are good and forgivable for the date of the title. The character models are, well, odd. and their animations are dopey to say the least. The game takes place in a single town called Paradise, the town is small but "♥♥♥♥♥quot; to navigate I had to pull up the map a good 100 times. Overall I would say that I personally enjoyed Postal 2, it is certainly not perfect but a good way to kill time. 6/10 Oh and the Apocalypse Weekend is terrible, do not bother with it.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
☭AH MAH GASH U CAN PEE ON PEOPLE. TENOUTTATEN!☭ Ahem. This review has been long coming. Postal 2 is an offensive to some, but if you can look past that you can really get some enjoyment out of this game. While the gunplay is average at best, the weapon variety is amazing. Scissors, Gas cans, Dynamite, Urine, Napalm Launcher, Sledgehammars etc. The story is simple. You are sent on errands by your nagging wife. It entirely up to you how you decide to behave. You can be a pacifist, not killing a single person using your wits and money to get out of arrest. Or for most players. You can go POSTAL. Gunning down all these people and rampaging through the town decaptating, burning, or otherwise maming your way through the game.  If it comes down to it, Would I reccomend? Yes.Some people are sensitive about a game like this, but you just need to listen up.Its low brow yes, but theres charm in that.Overall I enjoyed Postal 2 and if you bought it, you will too.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Having just purchased this on a whim, this is without a doubt one of the most enjoyable games I have played on PC. Granted I'm playing this on a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥laptop so it's hard to play a game made post-2006 but nonetheless this game is still fantastic. The graphics are nothing spectacular (even for a game released in 2003) but what makes this enjoyable is the open world and the endless carnage you get to unleash upon it. From the moment I beat someone to death with a shovel, set them alight and then urinated on their torched corpse I knew I was in for a fun time. The shooting mechanics are nothing amazing and pretty basic; but it's using the melee weapons where the game truly shines. Dismembering screaming bystanders witha set of hedge clippers was a morbid delight. Having purchased the complete Postal 2 collection (including Weekend Apocalypse) and having thoroughly enjoyed my experience I was delighted to see that DLC was available for the game 11 YEARS since the last expansion. I also got myself Paradise Lost and hhave just started this. So far, it's been a juvenile delight with plenty of cussing, blood and shameless toilet humour. If you're looking for something that will metally and physically challenge you, pushing your gaming skills to the test; or you're seeking an in-depth and engaging story then this is not the game for you. However, if you're looking to indulge you childish humour, primitive bloodlust or just have a really crappy PC that won't run anything made within the last ten years, then this is the game for you.Good job, Running With Scissors! You've earned yourself another fan!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Postal 2 is a fun FPS sandbox experience, however it is recommended that if you are easily offended, just walk away. It's addictive and very challenging at harder levels. The main story is not that great, and mainly varies from doing different errands, such as cashing a paycheck or returning a library book. How you do them, however, is up to you. You can just simply walk into the bank and cash your paycheck, or you can sneak into the vault and take whatever loot you can carry, and also murder half the population of the town. Its a fun little time waster and is even better with the hundreds of weapons mods. Also, the multiplayer, while fun, is very empty. Not to mention, you can urinate on people.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Now the flowers will grow!What's there left to say about POSTAL 2? POSTAL 2 stands out from most every video game ever, even 10 years later. It's funny and it's fun and that's all you need. The game is a week in the life of Postal Dude (from Paradise, AZ) Who is Postal Dude? Postal Dude is just a dude. A dude who is postal, or in other words, just doesn't give a f**k. What is an average week in the life of POSTAL dude? POSTAL dude embarks in the herculean adventure of getting some milk, returning a library book, cashing a check, and making a confession at the local church. The catch? POSTAL dude can and will be obscene and violent as he can. POSTAL dude will♥♥♥♥♥♥on, shoot, tase, kick, beat-with-a-shovel, or set fire to anyone or anything he (you) wants. Oh yeah, and cashing that check? You can just rob the bank. This game is as funny as it is offensive. If you are easily offended, you should probably grow a spine, because this game picks on everybody. Women, middle easterners, gay men, and police officers among everyone else. However, Running With Scissors is self aware. They pick fun at theirselves. They know their game is violent, offensive, and plot-less, and that's the point.
